    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2013-07-07: This battery has given life to my phone for up to three days straight, it is absolutely wonderful. I just wish the back cover was a little more durable

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-30: Takes for ever to charge but it is a huge battery. The fit takes a big phone and makes it huge.

    2014-03-24: It is greatly extending the life of my phone. The cover fits the phone perfectly. Highly recommend it. It is more convenient than any external batteries.

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-08: Updated review: July 5th, 2014, original review below.I bought another of these batteries, this time the seller was Beesclover. This one almost seems like a different product! the battery fits into the phone more snuggly and the cover looks and feels different, fiting the phone much better than the first purchase or its replacement (see original review below). Also of interest, the antenna is now white instead of black, as for the functionality of the antenna I cannot comment at this time as I haven't attempted any purchases with this new cover in place.All in all this purchase has been an improvement over my initial purchase from Crazy Cart.Original review:When I recieved the first battery from Crazy Cart I had my suspicions, the label was faded and there was a slight smudged spot as if the ink on the lettering had been rubbed off. I suspected a previously used product. My suspicions only grew greater when, after the six recommended charge/discharge cycles, the battery gave me no more discharge time than the OEM battery that came with my phone.I contacted Crazy Cart and after some emailing back and forth they finally sent me a replacement. Right out of the package I could see a difference, the label on the new battery was brightly colored and all lettering was bold and distinct. The battery delivered a full ten hours of discharge time with regular use after the first twelve hour charge/discharge cycle and after the recommended six cycles the battery is giving me anywhere from fourteen to twentyfour hours depending on my usage, and will actually trickle up during standby mode.The one weakness that this product has, and I found this to be true with both the first and second shipments, is the battery cover. It doesn't seat properly at the corner where the SPen sets and there is a tiny gap along the top edge that collects debri.I do like the rubbery feel of the cover, it is much easier to grip than the slicker OEM battery cover. I do wish the cover was more streamlined like those made for the international version of the Galaxy Note, the gel cover I bought to use with the extended battery would have no open gap where the window is cut for the camera lens and flash. It is a matter of function determining shape however and in this case the manufacturer had to accomodate the antenna that is part of the ATT version of the Note.in conclusion I take off one star for the failing of the first battery shipped to me and a second star for the poor fit of the battery cover, the replacement battery itself works as described. I may end up buying a second one as I travel occassionally and planes have no accomodations for charging a cell phone.

In fact, it seems to drain significantly faster than the factory battery. If anyone has any sort of voodoo charging methods to alleviate this problem it'd be much appreciated.   • B003ZZXLHQ

    $B003ZZXLHQ

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2014-02-19: I didn't perform a drop test on my company but I bet that it could absorb a 4' drop with no problem. The case is very large but offered the protection that I was looking for. It's actually a case over a case. The clip also has a lock to prevent accidental drops.

    Rating: 4

    2011-01-19: It was great for protection, but if you have to remove the case for any reason (resetting phone), be careful, the claw on the outer shell broke and was unable to attach to phone properly.

    Rating: 3

    2011-02-17: I'm writing this review to help any buyers who need to make the decision on Otterbox Defender vs Seido Rugged. I purchased the Otterbox Defender case a month ago. The Defender case is good but has faults. I wrote a review on Amazon about the Defender case if you need to read in depth my reasoning for replacing it with the Seido case.The Seido is ALOT better than the Defender case. The case comes in 3 parts. An inside plastic shell which snaps together PERFECTLY unlike the Defender case that squeaks whenever you press a button. The second set of protection is the silicone cover. The third is another hard plastic partial cover which provides extra protection to the impact zones of the phone. This piece is very important. My Otterbox's inside case chipped at the top left corner from a fall...with the Seido Case this would not happen because it has the extra protection at the corners. The seido case also leaves no openings except for the speaker and mic holes. Seido leaves the option to use your own screen protector. The Otterbox forces you to use its built in screen protector. The biggest plus of the Seido case is the holster. The case fits my wide police duty belt perfectly, something the Otterbox could not do. Great case, just upset that i spent money on the Otterbox first.UPDATE: After a month, the holster release latch broke off while i was taking the phone from the holster....not so durable for a "RUGGED" case/holster. Sigh...took one star off.

    Rating: 4

    2010-11-13: I ordered the Rugged because I work construction and my phones take a beating. But I really only need two things, some sort of protection if/when I drop it and a holster that is easy to get my phone in and out of with some sort of positive feedback that it's locked in place. I picked the Rugged because, well it was rugged, had a camera cover and the holster looked like it would secure the phone but be easy to insert/release the phone.It is definitely rugged, the case itself is made up of a sandwich of a hard plastic interior case (the Innocase Surface), silicon middle case and then a spider like exterior cover that mostly protects the back and corners. This sandwich like design seems like a reasonable method of dissipating the energy from a fall. I happen to like the bulk created by the case, it makes it easier to hold for me, but be warned that the combined bezel created by the layers is really thick, and I am unable to get to the edges of the screen (I am completely unable to move icons between screens with this cover on). What's really mind boggling is that given the additional bulk from this case, it's not designed to work with the extended battery. (I think the mixed reports of it actually working has to do with the fact that there are two different versions of the Verizon extended battery ~1800mah and ~1930mah but I honestly don't know)The camera cover is just a flap of the silicon portion of the middle case, it's not a sliding plastic door like I thought the picture shows. This is a big problem in my opinion and one of the reasons that this case will have to be returned. The silicon flap when closed rests against the camera lens window itself. This means that any dirt or abrasive material that gets in there will scratch the camera window, the exact thing I'm trying to avoid.The holster itself is sturdy, has a ratchet style turning belt clip and definitely holds the entire assembled case firmly. The only problem is that the design of the spring loaded retention is shaped in a way that when putting the phone into the holster on your hip, there is a very likely chance that the clip will hit the screen first, not the bezel. This is the deal breaker for me, I'm not going to subject the screen of the phone to repeated strikes from the case that is supposed to protect it.If you're the kind of person who is disciplined enough to place the phone in the holster perfectly every time, then this isn't a problem for you. But to be quite honest, I smash my phone into the holster constantly all day long, making sure I have perfect technique is not my primary concern.Also worth mentioning; as someone else pointed out, the location for the directions is just bizarre. The directions are split into two papers, one sits inside the case where the phone itself goes, if you're careful you can remove it without completely tearing it, then the second piece of paper is actually sandwiched between the inner case and the silicon case (IIRC). Very odd choice of packing directions considering the large blister pack the whole thing comes in.Normally my reviews are not this negative, I guess I'm frustrated. All I really need is a holster that's as simple as the one for my blackberry. In all it's not a bad case, but it's not the case for me, I'm going to have to keep looking.

    Rating: 3

    2011-03-09: This has to be the best case for your Droid X if you need rugged protection. I use the holster and carry on my belt so the face in protection is a must and I love the flaps that cover and protect all the ports and camera. I have never dropped my phone but I am certain that this case would protect it to the fullest if I ever did! The only complaint I can even think of would be that the holster belt clip isn't adjustable...meaning it fits up to a 2" "duty" belt so on my regular 1.5" belt it has room to move up and down; but it really isn't a big deal at all.You will absolutely not go wrong with this case if ultimate protection is what you need!!

    Rating: 5

    2011-08-14: The Item was more than I expected. It appears to be very durable. I believe the case is of a very good design.It has two cases. You first install an outer shell which works good on its own. Then there is a silicone glove that goes over the shell providing a very durable cover. In addition there is a outer plastic corner protector that helps protect the covers and keeps the silicone glove secure. The sylone protect the buttons and camera lens.Very nice concept.The reason for the three stars is the belt clip. I cary a book bag. The second week of usage I had an incomming call, I removed my phone to anwer the call when I arrived to the car an remove my book bad the bag caught on the belt clip and broke it. I do not know the answer but I would suggest protecting the belt clip when the phone is not in its holder. I also noticed this clip tends to get caught on my seat belt.I believe the case will do an excellent job protecting the phone just be careful with the belt clip, especially if the phone is not in it.I have an old Motorola belt clip that works with the hard plasic inner shell of this case. I plan to see if the belt clip can be purchased seperately. I work in a steel mill and the environment is very harsh.

    Rating: 3

    2011-11-05: I originally purchased the Otterbox Defender and was happy with it for awhile. (2 mos.) The outer silicone casing streched out on me leaving it sloppy where it covers the buttons on the bottom. I wasn't too fond of the buttons being covered in the first place. Ok, that I dealt with. Next the built in screen protector on the Otterbox seperated from the top inner snap-on cover. Ok, enough is enough! I ordered the Seidio Convert and couldn't be happier. The outer silicone case cover is held on by a plastic/nylon? exo-skeleton shell which holds the silicone in place perfectly and I'm happy that my four bottom buttons aren't covered. Problem solved. I do give credit to Otterbox because when I called their warranty number, they are sending out a brand new whole case assembly priority shipping as soon as they get more in stock. In conclusion I would have to say it's a user's preference as to which style and the Otterbox is less expensive.

    Rating: 5

    2010-12-31: I've been using this case and holster for about a month and I'm very pleased with it.Yes, it definitely makes the phone look very large, but I kinda like that and it's a big phone to begin with.I always use it with the rugged skin and holster so can't comment on the innocase but I did have to pull the battery on it a few days ago and it was a pain in the butt to undress all the layers from it.I don't think it's realistic to think it will protect the phone from shocks of being dropped, nor will any case for that matter, but I'm confident it will keep the phone from getting scratched and I dropped it in mushy snow last week and having the multiple layers protected the phone from moisture intrusion.Here's what I don't like...The camera lens cover is definitely a must have, but this little flap is difficult to open and it doesn't want to stay plugged in to the little slot, resulting in the rubber flap photobombing its fair share of pictures.The port and jack flaps are a must have too but I can see all rubber flaps breaking off after some time but especially the camera lens flap.They can improve the belt clip by simply terminating it at 270 degrees. This one gets stuck on your underwear or pans or belt when you try to pull it off. By looping it around like two way radio belt clips, this would not be a problem.I do find that dirt, lint and pet hair sticks to the rubber and felt. But better that than get inside the phone.One of the reviewers complained that you have to carefully put it back in the case so as not to smash the display. I was concerned about this but I haven't found that to be a problem because if you miss, the holser touches the speaker area. In my view, you'd have to be really careless or uncoordinated to accidently smash the top of the holser into the display.I would definitely recommend this and buy another. This is the best rugged case and holster I have seen.

    Rating: 4

    2013-01-28: Good and small but just feels cheap. It doesn't provide a whole lot of protection for the phone. The clip and the case break pretty easily but Sedio replaces them for free.

    Rating: 3

    2012-11-16: In order to help Motorola build the best mobile phone possible, I'm writing with some brief pros and cons regarding the DROID RAZR HD.PROS:Motorola Smart ActionsPhone build/design (e.g. DuPont(tm) Kevlar fiber, Corning Gorilla Glass, and a water repellent nano-coating.)Long battery lifeSpeaker locationMicrophone locationRemovable storage (microSD)Stripped down UILED IndicatorScreen dominates most of phone sizeCONS:RAM (need 2GB min.)Bloatware (VZW grrr)Camera takes so-so quality photosNo quad core processor

    Rating: 4

    2013-06-23: I recently replaced a Razr MAXX with an "HD" version and the only significant differences are negative, not positive.Under Google's new ownership of the cell phone division of Motorola, the SIM and supplemental memory cards are now physically inaccessible unless you bring a little key to release the tray that they both sit in. Horrible.When removing the tray, the SIM card immediately falls on the floor. The microSD card does not even sit in the tray, so you have to remember that it's supposed to be placed by hand into the slot of the phone, with the tray and SIM card carefully balanced to be pushed back into the side of the phone for the retaining catch to hold this all in place. Did I say horrible?When connected through the USB cable to a computer, the new operating system no longer lets a user "see" the cell phone's internal memory and microSD card as separate drives. They want you to download, install, and use a Google software management application.Previously, when connecting the USB cable, you got three popups on your computer monitor: an earlier software management application (that you didn't have to use), a "windows" type file folder query for the internal phone folders, and another "windows" type file folder query for quick access to the folders on the microSD card.SO, the quick way to now get to your photos and videos moved over to your home computer is to remove the microSD card and use a card reader. Oh, wait, what if I forgot or lost the dang key? (see aforementioned)Minor additional problems they have created include moving some of the function icons around on the touch screen. Takes some getting used to, that's all, but there is no clear advantage to their having done so, hence, it's judged "negative."Another problem is that they have moved the camera lens to the upper center of the backside of the phone, right where your hand typically touches. Smeared lens and blurry photos follow. When the lens was in the corner, they picked a spot that ordinarily is in the clear. So this was change for the negative.The USB and HDMI jacks are exposed, no protective cover to keep dust out. They've also relocated these jacks to the lower left corner as you look at the operating screen, so you may need to re-route your charging cable. In that location, both jacks are more likely to pick up dirt. I'll probably put a piece of electrical tape over the holes because as soon as dust gets near there, the cable pushed in pushes in the dirt too.Nice screen, nice battery. My selected APPs work well, and I've given up complaining about all the bloatware included with the phone. Just like the earlier Razr MAXX. The "HD" is more marketing than substance.

    Rating: 4

    2013-03-15: This is a great phone. I've had it a couple months now. Good reception, very long battery life, even though it's not the Maxx model, and never drops Bluetooth connectivity. I had the predecessor to this, the Droid X, for a couple years, and was very satisfied with it, but moved up to the Razr because it's 4G and a better screen. It's also faster, of course. It has a solid, sturdy feel to it, which i like. I had considered the S3 but was put off with it by some reports of overheating (!) and screen fragility issues. The Razr is not fragile, as I can attest to.My only complaint is that it's every hard to see the screen outdoors. If you use yours outdoor a lot, try it in a store and walk outside to see how it looks before purchasing. I'm going to change screen protectors to see if that helps. I'm using using Fosmon brand on it, so I doubt that's the problem. I don't take many pics with it, but the ones I've taken are good quality, which is fine. Primarily I use it for business, where I log about 2,000 minutes a month with a Bluetooth headset. That requires only an every-other day charge, and even then it's only down to about 30% the end of the second day. I haven't had any issues with lockups or related problems. I've also used it as a mobile hotspot for my laptop and it had good throughput for that.For every day heavy usage and good reception, I recommend this phone.

    Rating: 5

    2013-02-04: This phone has to be one of the top 5 Android phones available right now. One thing that made this phone stand out from the competition is the build quality. It feels rock solid with its KEVLAR backing, Gorilla Glass, and a water-repellent nanocoating for added assurance.I've owned this phone for about 6 weeks now and the performance is 2nd to none. Call quality is great even on the speaker phone; and the battery life is above average for a smartphone with this size of display and performance specs. Motorola has done a very good job of minimizing their presence within the Android OS, while still providing some very useful custom apps, such as SMARTACTIONS, Circles and the Quick Settings menu. SMARTACTIONS allows you to automate tasks based on conditions; for example if your battery power drops below 25%, it will automatically adjust the display brightness, and turn off the WiFi or any other feature you elect to change. The conditions are not limited to battery power; it can be based on your GPS location, like silencing your ringer while at work, or based on time of day, etc... "Circles" is a nice widget that displays information of your choosing such as time, weather, battery level etc... With "Quick Settings" you simply swipe to the left from the home screen to access frequently used settings.As many other reviewers have stated, the one area this phone falls short is the camera. Despite its 8.0MP rating, it does not perform very well in most environments. My experience has been that pictures are grainy and colors are not true. I was aware of the poor camera reviews before I purchased the phone, so I had an idea of what I was getting. Although a better camera would be really nice; I have a DSLR that I use at events where I desire high quality photos so it wasn't a deal breaker for me, but for others it might be; especially because some of the competitors have really outstanding cameras.

    Rating: 4

They kept getting bigger, and more numerous, so I took it to an Apple store to see what could be done. Lo and behold, I removed the protector and my screen was absolutely fine. It has been fine since I have stopped using protectors. You don't need them!

    2012-02-15: In light of the absolute idiocy of so many people that traffic this site, I'll rewrite this review to clarify what I was saying before.I wanted this earpiece to be great, I got it with the intention of loving it, the only thing I don't like about the old school earpiece is that it's uncomfortable after a while. So I had no reason to prime myself with negative thinking towards this device. However, when it got here, it didn't waste any time making me a very unhappy customer. I have a lot, and I mean a LOT of bluetooth devices, everything from speakers, to conference speakers, to hands free speaker kits for the truck, headphones, ipods, all my computers, you name it, I've likely got it, I even have an older mp3 player watch around here somewhere with bluetooth... Anyways, the point is, I'm familiar with the system empirically and educationally, and my HTC HD7 had a hell of a time with this peripheral. My plantronics 925 pairs up to it in less than a minute once you have it in pairing mode, this piece took me a good 45 minutes, not because I didn't know what I was doing, but because there was something going on with the bluetooth mechanism in the earpiece.Something that seems to have pissed off so many previous readers is that I said "I hate windows phones", and I do, the operating system sucks and the UI is outright retarded. Splitting hairs with me over whether or not the HD7 is a "windows/microsoft product" or not is completely pointless, as the point is, it is a "windows phone", and it didn't work well with the "xbox earpiece". Do I have to be a comedian and say it in a funny voice for the levity of that to not fly right over your heads?Anyways, once paired, the piece performed horridly, I couldn't walk more than 3 feet from the phone, and I had to keep the side of my head upon which the piece was mounted facing the phone at all times, as apparently my thick skull was enough to interrupt the connection. However, it was still comfortable, and has a great battery life, so I figured if "hell, if it works well on the xbox I'll still keep it". But it didn't. My gen1 wireless piece sounded better, and operated at a functional capacity to a greater distance than this one. So I sent it back.In all fairness, should I have gotten an exchange in case something was wrong with the piece I got? Maybe. But I didn't, I sent it back and said "f it", because this one was so bad I didn't really care to make another go at it. If they release another, improved one, I'll give it another shot, as the idea was great. But this piece deserves one star based on my experience with it, and that's what I gave it, I cannot with a good conscience suggest it to anyone.If you don't like this review because you somehow think my experience isn't to be trusted, keep it to yourself. I don't write these reviews to pander to an audience of idiot consumers that reinforce bad behavior and shoddy manufacturing from corporations, I write them for critically minded consumers who expect a full and functional experience out of what they buy. Period.

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2013-02-07: This is a great design for a phone case, and it performs beautifully. The slot on the back is the star of this case, for anyone who doesn't want to carry their purse or wallet when they go out. It holds one card securely or two cards very tightly. I was not at all concerned about losing my cards. The cards can be slid in and out easily, but will not come out on their own. This would be a great way to carry a hotel room cardkey while on vacation. The hard shell case matches the phone well and fits snugly. It provides just enough texture to make the phone easy to hold, but adds almost no bulk. Because it's a hard plastic there won't be any stretch over time taking cards out and putting them back. It provides protection on the top, bottom and corners from scratches and short drops. All the buttons are left open for easy access, and it is easy to plug in headphones or a charger. There is no stand, as indicated in the description.I gave this case five stars, even though it doesn't have a stand as the description says. I got it for the card slot feature and it performed beyond expectation. I will recommend this to friends.

    Rating: 5

    2013-02-10: This case provides great convenience while keeping your S3 protected. The case itself wraps around all the sides of the phone, including the top and bottom, leaving no corners or edges unprotected. It's raised up just a hair above the screen, so I don't know how well it will protect that. It's a fairly hard plastic, so it doesn't always come on and off the easiest, though it certainly doesn't feel like it will break when doing so, or crack from a drop. Overall, I feel comfortable keeping my phone in this case.The key feature of this case, however, is the card holder on the back. While it may make the phone slighly thicker overall, the convenience can't be denied for certain situations. Whether I'm going walking, hiking, running, playing sports, or going to the gym, its great to not have to bring my wallet. I simply tuck my license, a credit card, and either my student ID or a few folded bills in the back pocket of the case and I'm good to go! Makes it much easier when I can fit my phone in one pocket and my keys in my other and be set, considering gym shorts don't have back pockets. Plus, if your wallet is a little thick, it gives you the ability to leave it home even when wearing normal pants.Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone with a fairly active lifestyle. While it may not offer the most solid protection, its certainly enough for me, and its convenience can't be denied!

    2013-02-10: One of the high points of this case, and my biggest draw to it was the fact it only added a little extra bulk to the phone. part of the reasons I got the S3 to begin with was the fact it's so light and thin. Another thing I thought was a nice feature was the snap on part that goes around to the front of the phone adds just a very little lip so if you have this case on your phone and set it on your desk face down, it doesn't let the screen touch the desk. I was not willing to test the impact ability of this case but it isn't too rigid that your phone would take all the shock through the case and it's not too soft to do nothing for protection.Added Convince -The two slots on the side of the case that you can see in the pictures are not just there for aesthetics, that is a slot that's built in the phone so you can add a credit card or a identification card behind your phone. This has a cool side for the people that just want to carry only their phone around, however you can pretty much tell what card it is behind the case, and with the s3 being a hot phone, if someone were to steal it, they would then also have your card of choice with it. And I say card of choice due to the fact that you can pretty much only fit one card behind the phone without wedging them in, tried a debit card and my drivers licence and it was too tight.The case is pretty light, pretty thin, provides decent protection for the back of the phone, and if you want to carry ONE card with you under the case there's that option as well, all in all, nice product. (3 stars due to only fitting 1 card in the slot and too easy for people to tell that you're carrying a card with your phone.)

    Rating: 3

    2013-02-04: I am evaluating this product as a project. I like the feel of this product, the polycarbonate is malleable to be able to hold in your hand, yet not so rigid to be uncomfortable to use. I especially like the slot in the back of the case to allow the user to use it to store identification or credit cards. The weight is light and eliminates in cumbersome feeling when the case is attached to the phone. I did not see how the case can be used as a stand unless you push the phone part way out of the case to cause a tripod effect. The example here on the web site does not show how that is being used. I don't really think you can use this as a stand. I would have given the case a 5 star, except that the description of the stand did not seem logical. I like the color, the feel, the way it grabs the phone, should protect the front from scratches since it curves around the top and bottom of the phone. The case also is designed to easily and freely allow you to use a charger cable and a headset, without having to remove the phone from the case. I suggest it to be a good buy, but the stand needs to be clarified and an example put on the descriptive page to show how that works.

    Rating: 4

    2014-05-30: I have found the effective length between my phone and the car outlet is about 2.5 feet (30 inches or 76 cm). It goes probably double that, but 2.5 feet has been a very comfortable length for normal use. The only major consideration in purchasing the Universal Car Charger for Android is thus the length of the cord. I love the coiled feature as I'm always having straight cords get tangled in my gear shift, brake handle, etc. and this keeps things a lot cleaner. It also sits a lot nicer in the glove box which is pretty cluttered also. When I pick up my Moto-G it easily stretches for use, then gets compact again when I reholster my phone.So, I plugged in my Moto-G and the micro USB connector slid in perfectly yet wasn't loose telling me the machined tolerances are solid.     2014-06-12: The car charger works great, especially for devices that require more than the typical 0.5 A limit found on typical devices.However, the cord length of 4.9 feet may be somewhat misleading. While the coiled wire is welcome in terms of avoiding "self-entanglement", I found that the "recoil" on the cord to make its effective length about half that amount. When I'm trying to charge my Galaxy S3, I was fighting the recoil a bit and found the cord yanking out if I stretched it too long.To be fair, however, my phone is getting quite old (and heavily used) and I think the charging receptacle isn't what it used to be in terms of holding a cable properly. That said, I was able to use the cord to about 1/2 its advertised length with minimal fighting.     2014-06-22: UPDATE: 07/2014 PRODUCT HAS FAILEDThis charger failed during a long trip when I really needed to keep the smartphone powered up. Very disappointed. I had but ONE DAY remaining to be able to return for a replacement, and see that it is "out of stock" and not available for delivery until September?!?!?The LED went out, that normally indicates you are connected to a DC outlet in your car. Two other chargers work fine in that same outlet, and this unit does not work in any outlets in the vehicle (three were tried).The internal fuse of the unit is intact, has not blown, and there was no abnormal indication or use of the smartphone. I noticed that the charging unit had failed when the phone's icon for battery life remaining was far lower than normal.I limped along with the factory charging cord, which cannot keep up with both the phone in-use and charging the phone's battery.Although I'm glad Amazon's policy will cover a return and replacement, I hope the failure of this unit is not part of the China Syndrome of cheap products and poor quality control.Will update this review in a couple of months....-------(Original review follows. I had rated this device at four stars.)The higher power of this car charger allows me to get ahead of how much current the phone draws when I'm using it for navigation at full screen brilliance.The phone, a Motorola Razr Maxx, already has a beefy battery, but its extra capacity requires increased charging ability to bring it up to full.This device does that well.Car chargers with less power spend most of their time struggling to keep up with power demands of a smartphone that's being used. As a result, there's very little capacity left to actually charge the phone's battery, so it will take far longer than if you turn off the phone, or when using the somewhat stronger home charger.It's important to note that this charger shows no sign of overpowering the phone, which would present a risk of cooking the battery or burning up the phone's voltage regulator circuitry that governs the charging rate. Instead, because the phone operates normally, I conclude that this unit has the ability to supplement the power demanded by the phone, along with being able to recharge the battery.Recommended.

    Rating: 1

    2014-05-31: Car chargers at the big cell phone company stores are very expensive, so it’s good to have a basic alternative to provide a charge while on the go.The AmazonBasics Micro USB Universal Car Charger for Android has an output of 2.1 amps. The cord, when coiled, is pretty short (less than 10 inches) but uncoils to 4.9 feet. The charger fits easily and is easy to remove from my vehicles (I have used chargers that are sometimes hard to insert into the car’s DC adapter) and the other end fits nicely into my phone (Samsung Galaxy 5). It is built well and has a little light that illuminates when the unit is charging a device.Given the inexpensive price, I would certainly recommend the AmazonBasics Micro USB Universal Car Charger. If it holds up over time, this is a five star car charger for Android.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-29: This is a very good quality Micro USB car charger for Android and compatible devices with 2.1 Amp power output from a reputable company.I attempted this with multiple devices that accepts 'Micro USB' as the charging port and all of them readily accepted the power output given by this universal car charger with 2.1 Amp current output. My phone (Motorola Android based) My tablets (Kindle Fire and Kindle E-book readers) all accepted the charge without any fuss. Even couple of my Sony cameras accepted this charger as well. This ONE charger in your glove box will come handy for multitude of devices when needed. The unit does not get too hot when compared to most other brands I have used before which clearly tells me that the power conversion circuit inside this charger is efficient and not some cheapo linear IC 7805 with odd-ball resistor shunt knock-offs.BTW, The Amazon's price on this is very competitive. The best thing about this charger versus most other similar product from other manufacturers is that it comes with it's own coiled cord and Micro USB port which means less clutter in your glove box.Amazon is also selling a model with Lightning (connector) for newer Apple DevicesCheck this one outAmazonBasics Lightning Car Charger for iPhone, iPad and iPod (2.1 Amp Output) - Apple certifiedGood quality product. Why take risk from unknown brands with your expensive tablets and phones?- Five stars!

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-06: I've got a Samsung Smartphone that I use on the Walmart Family Mobile plan and this charger works fine with it. It's not the latest S5 but it is the workhorse T-Mobile model they had before the new one. It charges the battery back up in an hour and a half of driving around and of course it lets me use it immediately if the battery has died so I keep it handy in the glove compartment. I do recommend without reservation.

    Rating: 5

    2014-07-01: This charger is great to have in the car. I use it to power my phone while it is providing GPS directions. By the end of my car ride my phone is always fully charged. This charger quickly charges the phone and the cord coils up so you don't have a mess of wires when you're not using it.I have found that the coil can be too tight at time, pulling on my phone, but all you need to do it stretch it out for 10 seconds and it will be fine.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-07: This car charger is great. The cord is long but compact so it doesn't get tangled in anything else when I'm not using it and I can just keep the charger plugged in all the time. It's sturdy so I have no fear of tugging too hard on thin wires. Perfect car charger for my Samsung phone.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-05: Every one of AmazonBasics' line of products come similarly packed in a plain cardboard no-frills box with minimal if any instructions and nothing more. No clamshells or fancy point of sale packaging and it really underlines their basic approach to the product delivery as well a saving production cost and the environment from wasted lacking materials.However, one should not assume the product itself is lesser in quality and indeed this micro USB universal car charger is notable not only for is well thought out design but excellent construction and functionality.It's a single piece unit designed to charge android phones and tablets or any device using a micro USB port. Since it offers a hefty 2.1 amps it can charge aforementioned tablets at the same speed as your wall charger and even allow you to use the device as it's charging. The flexible coiled cable stretches from about a foot to four or so enabling your passengers the necessary reach to use the phone at a distance as it charges.So nothing basic about the product itself; it works good, is well built all at an insanely low price.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-25: I have a couple of car chargers for my GN3 that I've been using. However, at best, they might be able to prevent the phone from dying while in use. Why is that? Well the Galaxy Note 3 is a larger and powerful phone, which normally uses a 2.0 amp charger. Most car chargers either can't provide this or only work at full amperage with fruit products.So enter the AmazonBasics Micro USB universal charger to save the day. For my test and typical use-case scenario, I put my phone on my dash mount, fired up some navigation software (Waze, in this instance), maxed out the screen brightness, and went for a drive. Should also note I keep all radio's on at all times, including Bluetooth for hands-free calling, Wi-Fi, 4G/LTE, and GPS, of course.After about 15-20 minutes, the battery percentage had actually increased by 5%. Success! If this was any less than 2.0 amp, that simply wouldn't happen.Beyond that there isn't much to say. It's a basic charger design with a coiled cable that's just the right length. While it may go to over 4 ft, it was pretty stiff going past 3 ft. Although I already got that impression from the pictures Amazon posted. And for most dashes, this is more than enough. Any longer and you'll want a straight cable.Overall, I consider it highly recommended for any Android user - even though it will likely work with plenty others.

    Rating: 5

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2014-05-19: My husband has been using a stylus pen for some time ... he loves the convenience of it. However, I have struggled with the style of his because it is too narrow.This is actually the perfect fit for my hand - not too thick, not too thin. The Capacitive end works well and appears to be made at least as sturdily as the others I have used and tested. Even after pressing hard on it, it did not move.When you are ready to use the pen, you remove the top and place it over the other end, protecting it while you use the pen. The colors and styling of the pen make it very professional looking. The only thing that would keep me from giving this as a gift is the fact it doesn't come in it's own case!I received a complimentary sample to test for my review and am pleased enough that I am actually carrying it and using it. Five Stars. A comfortable pen and stylus.

    Rating: 5

    2014-03-10: I was provided some free samples of styluses for review. They were (in case you are interested in other options for a stylus):*Sty-HD 9 pcs Rainbow of Colors Capacitive Stylus/Styli Touch Screen Cellphone Tablet Pen for iPhone 4 4s 3 3Gs iPod Touch iPad 2 Motorola Xoom, Samsung Galaxy, BlackBerry Playbook AMM0101US, Barnes and Noble Nook Color, Droid Bionic*Business Stylus Executive Pen - Capacitive Stylus Touch Screen Cellphone Tablet Pen for iPhone 5 4 4s 3 3Gs iPod Touch iPad 2 3 4 Motorola Xoom, Samsung Galaxy S4 S3, Barnes and Noble Nook Color, Droid Bionic*Sty-HD 2 Pack of Premium Precision Micro-Knit Hybrid Fiber Tip Capacitive Stylus Pens for iPhone 5 4 4s, iPod touch, All iPad: 1st Gen, 2, the NEW iPad, iPad 4th gen with Retina display, iPad Mini, Samsung Galaxy Tablet and Phone Black and Silver Color*Sty-HD 17 pcs Colorful 3 Styles Capacitive Stylus/Styli Touch Screen Cellphone Tablet Pen for iPhone 4 4s 3 3Gs iPod Touch iPad 2 Motorola Xoom, Samsung Galaxy, BlackBerry Playbook AMM0101US, Barnes and Noble Nook Color, Droid BionicAt first I was disappointed in all the styli I received due to responsiveness, but I later figured out that I needed to apply more pressure. If you do not apply enough pressure, it will be unresponsive on some devices, with some devices requiring more pressure than others. While you don't have to apply a whole lot of pressure, just a light touch of the stylus may not work, so keep this in mind. Also, keeping the stylus perpendicular to the plane of the device works better in many cases (though not usually necessary). If these are issues for you, then you may not like using a stylus.Using a stylus helps keep fingerprints off your device, which is a nice benefit.My review for this executive pen stylus is as follows.I like the handiness of a single stylus and real writing pen. The real writing pen writes well (in black ink) and I'd say is more of a finer point than a medium point. The pen clip is real metal unlike others which is often chrome colored plastic.The overall quality of this executive pen is higher than most others and the heft of it gives it a nice feel.Some reviews complain of dented pens, but my pen arrived without any dents.Overall 4 stars because it's not as responsive as a real finger, but it works well enough with a moderate amount of pressure applied.

    Rating: 4

    2014-05-17: This is a very nice and well appointed stylus, but being a bit more expensive than many others I'm holding it to a little higher set of standards.First of all, this IS a very attractive pen overall, and it's got a nice feel to it. Rather than being slick and glossy, the barrel has a slight "gun metal" feel to it which I found very pleasant to hold in my hands and less prone to being dropped. I personally prefer a fatter barrel, but I know there are many who like a slim one, and I think this will certainly appeal not only to women, but many men as well: the slim barrel and gold trim lend more of an "executive" look to it...to use the pen's own descriptive term.I very much liked the rubbery capacitive tip (capacitive refers to "screen" technology that can detect a "touch" without applying pressure). I love using these tips, and I used the Sty-HD a lot on my phone screen and Kindle. I found it to be quite agreeable to use. I found no unpleasant "drag time" issues with the tip and thought it seemed to be very responsive. I don't foresee any problems with its strength or durability, either.I am not that impressed with its pen, however. While part of my problem is not the pen's "fault," really, as I prefer a rollerball or gel tip, I took issue with the fact that the pen tip felt "draggy" and dryish. I don't know what kind of a refill the Sty-HD has, as the refill has no information on its exterior, but I was not that impressed with its writing ability and would be more impressed with the pen if I could slip in a more impressive writing instrument.Somewhat related to this is another problem as I see it: the stylus tip is HIDDEN when the pen is open. To me, it would make more sense if the pen were to be usable as a writing implement AND a stylus if the stylus tip was on the end of the UPPER barrel rather than the lower one. If the stylus were on the very top part of the pen case -- the part that must be taken off to get at the pen -- then the stylus would remain usable when the pen was out. I suppose some might say that this arrangement might create leakage problems for the more forgetful of us who might forget to put the cap back on when they put the pen back in their pocket, but I believe the argument for making the pen completely usable when open trumps that.So, I found the Sty-HD to be a fine stylus, but an inferior pen. If you want a stylus with a sleek look, a great feel, and nice capacitive responsiveness, and are only passably interested in a pen, then this is your stylus.NOTE: I was supplied this product free of charge with no other conditions other than my writing a fair and honest review -- which this is.

    Rating: 3

    2014-03-13: This has a nice, executive look and feel...like a nice pen. One end is the rubber nub stylus and the other end is a pen tip designed to work on screen handwriting apps. Both ends work perfectly. I have a galaxy Note and this works great with that. It also works well on my iPad writing app.This is a really nice stylus and would make a great gift. You might want to get a pen box for it if you give it as a gift as it just comes in a plastic bag.I was provided a sample for honest test and review. If this sucked, I would say so. I review a lot of stuff and a lot of stuff sucks and I say it sucks. But this doesn't suck and I will update if at some point it starts to suck.

    Rating: 3

    2014-03-16: *Disclosure: I was contacted by a representative for StyHD and given a sample of this product specifically for the purpose of giving my thoughts on it.*HTC OneHTC EVO 4G LTESamsung Galaxy S2Samsung Galaxy S3Samsung Galaxy S4Samsing Galaxy NexusiPad MiniiPad AirGoogle Nexus 7 (original)Tegra Note 7For this review, I'm going to be comparing three different models of Sty-HD styli which I was sent samples of. This one, theSty-HD 17 pcs Colorful 3 Styles multipack, and theSty-HD 2 Pack of Premium Precision Micro-Knit Hybrid Fiber Tip. Of the three, the multipack set is the most generic. Made almost completely in plastic with some plating to look like metal, this type of stylus, perhaps the exact same stylus, can be bought from a wide selection of vendors at different prices. In use, they work pretty ok, but not perfectly. The glide is a little off, especially with matte screen protectors. During testing, I noted that these tend to not work as well with Apple devices compared to Android models. Pressing slightly harder on the Apple screens would get better functionality, but rapid movement across the screen didn't work consistently. Overall, tolerable performance for the cheap price, hence the three stars which matches Amazon's "It's OK" meaning. Compared to its brethren, they work as well as the Business stylus, but lack the pen. Speaking of the Business model, though asking a premium price, its performance isn't any better than the one from the multipack as they share the same type of tip. It looks more business like, true, but even the pen doesn't work great. After cleaning the tip of the pen to clear off the seal to prevent ink leaking out while in shipping, I found the writing to be uneven and scratchy. I could literally hear the ball in the tip scratching at the the paper. To me, not worth the current price of nine bucks, and three stars for it. That leaves this model with the hybrid fiber tip. Of all three, these performed the best across the board. Much better glide and screen response. Still not perfect, as rapid movement would miss on occasion, but certainly a cut above the others. Again, the Apple devices didn't these as much as Android devices did, and matte screen protectors deteriorated the performance slightly. Comparing all three to the stylus that comes with my Tegra Note, the Tegra's stylus is the easy winner in all subjective and objective testing. This is not a surprise really, as the stylus and screen of the Tegra Note were designed specifically to work together. In the end, if you're wanting a decent stylus, hybrid tip is the one I'd suggest buying from Sty-HD.

    Rating: 3

    2014-03-13: This is a nice combination pen & stylus. This is great for presenters who use iPads or other tablets for presentations.The barrel is thick enough to grip well. The fine tipped pen writes well (black ink) and the rubber stylus tip is great on any tablet surface (iPad, Kindle Fire, etc.). This is a great accessory if you need a stylus.I was provided this item for review.

    2014-03-17: And now I've read that another reviewer had the same experience! As she gave it a 3-star average rating, obviously she thought that was acceptable. Not me! I'll tell it like it is! I'm not going to pay--time-wise or money-wise--for some company's lack of concern for its customers.And, can you believe that this company sent me this stylus for free hoping I'd write a review for them, and obviously didn't even care that they were sending me a flawed product.A word about the length of this pen: It starts out looking like a normal length "executive's" pen, but when the cap is removed to expose the writing point, the pen shortens to an unmanly 4 1/2".A word about the stylus end: The rubber is thin and sometimes dimples (and stays dimpled). Because it is such a thin rubber it doesn't have the resilience to work every time. It gives way and you end up pushing on the flat ridge under the rubber bulb.A word about the ball point: The point is fine. The ball does not roll easily and therefore the roll feels scratchy rather than smooth.

    2014-03-17: I've tried a variety of styli over the years, and I've never found one I really liked. Pogo made one that was great, but it was too short and thin. Some of the others had rubber tips that would create enough friction with the screen to make it difficult to slide around. This stylus avoids all the shortcomings of the others I've tried. It's is the size of a traditional ballpoint pen, so it's very easy and comfortable to hold. The tip is made out of a soft rubber that glides smoothly over the surface of whatever device you are using.I tested this out on my Galaxy Note 2, my wife's S4 and Kindle Fire, as well as on a friend's iPhone 4, and the stylus performed perfectly on all the devices. I could care less about the ballpoint pen in the opposing end of the stylus, but it does write smoothly and the whole thing is well weighted and comfortable in my hand.I didn't pay for this product, as I received one to test out and review, but I paid $8.95 for the Pogo one I have and I like this one much better. This is definitely five stars all the way in my book. In fact, I'd give it six stars if I were allowed.

    2013-11-13: The best cradle/car mount I've ever see. You just lay down your phone and connect your charger to the cradle dock. You can also remove the bottom piece so your phone fits with the case on. Designed perfectly with a lot of detail and functions perfectly every use.

    Rating: 5

    2011-08-18: I really like this dock. It appears to be well made and holds the EVO 3D just fine. I like the fact that it allows you to charge the phone while docked and that it automatically places the phone into Car Dock mode when docked.I did have a couple of minor issues with the dock. There is an insert that can be removed if you use a case for your phone to provide more room for the case. It works fine with rubber type cases as long as they are not too thick but the space was not quite wide enough for my hard case. I had to use a Dremmel tool to file away more space for my hard case but it works great now. Another issue is the suction cup tends to detach from the window a little too easy compared to some other devices I've used. It does work but I have had it fall several times. Also, the manual that came with it and the website shows two pivot points on this dock. The ball joint works as described but the arm is supposed to pivot as well. The manual and website show it has a cap that can be loosened to allow it to pivot and tightened to lock it into place but mine does not have this option. It is permanently locked into one position. It works fine attaching it to the window but if I wanted to use the part that attaches to the dash (permanently stocks to allow a flat attachment point), the pivot cannot be adjusted to all the suction to be used in this vertical mode. It appears the bolt and screwcap that allows this pivot to work has been replaced with a permanent bolt and cap. I was surprised the manual in the box clearly shows this can be loosened and adjusted but the part to be loosened has been replaced. If they redesigned the item they should have updated the manual that came in the box as well. You would think the website would be updated as well. I emailed support about this but never even received a response.

    Rating: 4

    2011-10-29: Excellent car mount! I have my HTC 3D in a TPU case and it fits inside this mount perfectly. The mount has a removable insert that when kept in place - provides perfect fit for a phone without a case. When the insert is removed - then a phone in a thin case (like TPU or silicone, I suppose) would fit in nicely. Not sure about bulky plastic cases though - those you will have to try on your own. Additionally - one the camera lenses remains open, which will allow you to record video while driving. The second lens is covered by the mount, so no 3D recording.Solid construction and adjustable for pretty much any possible angle of the windshield. Overall an excellent car mount for HTC 3D.

    2013-05-12: ok so I have tried sooo many Bluetooth headsets it seems i have become a bit of an expert.I am in construction and whether its on equipment, in my truck, or on a ladder I need a reliable Bluetooth with great range, good noise reduction, and killer battery life.This unit covers them all...and in spades.I found a 35-40ft connection range with a Samsung 3s. And connections were quick and fast even if the headset was off and in my pocket I could flip open the boom (this is how you turn the unit on) and catch a call!The noise reduction is a step up especially the wind noise reduction feature.The ear fit made this my new favorite for all day wear. (A sided note here. I generally use a med fitted insert on most headsets, but found I had to use the small. My wife could not get a good fit. So I would be concerned for women or men with small ears...try the fit before you buy.)The fit issue for my wife is why I deducted half a star.Battery life has averaged 3 days so about 8 hours of talk time...which is the best I have ever tested.Buttons are intuitive and easy, love the boom flip open to turn on and the volume controls...again best I have ever used ...One other quirky feature....not a knock...but a heads up...the power save feature....it turns the unit to sleep mode to safe battery life....it meant I had to touch the answer button and wait for the headset to awake before it would answer the call. I only had a problem with this if i had roamed out of range. As the unit was in sleep mode it did not warn me I was out of range...like say with a disconnection tone ...I got used to this and simply paid more attention to my distance to the phone...)I would buy another and recommend to anyone as with the caution of the fit issue for those with small ears.

    2013-04-22: I have been using the Jabra Supreme for about a year when I received this Bluetooth. I've been using it for several days now and find it as good as the Jabra Supreme. In respect to comfort on the ear it is superior. It is very light and can be worn for hours, in fact you will forget it is on. The sound quality is comparable to the Supreme. If you voice text, the Jabra Motion is superior. I am able to text paragraphs through voice texting will little or no misunderstood errors. I have not tried to sync it to any other devices outside of my Windows base HTC cell phone. Another very nice feature is it has a full 7 hour talk time vs. the Supreme only has 5 hours. This means it only has to be charged 1-2 times a week. I personally think that Jabra makes the best Bluetooth on the market. I have tried them all, including the high end Plantronics Voyager, which in my view is not even in the same league as this Bluetooth. The volume is unacceptable. Additionally you have to pay extra for voice commands after one year which is also unacceptable.. If you make you living talking on the phone or making appointments this Bluetooth is the best choice you can make as far as functionality and clarity.

    Rating: 5

    2013-05-29: The Jabra Motion is a great headset on its own, but isn't worth a price nearly twice that of comparable Plantronics headsets.For most high-end headsets these days, call quality is consistently high. The Jabra Motion is no exception- callers heard me clearly and I heard them as well. But for someone like me who has tried dozens of different headsets and carries no less than three headsets at any given time, the devil, as they say, is in the details.The Jabra Motion stands out above my go-to headset, thePlantronics Voyager PRO+, with two excellent features: an adjustable-height earpiece and the flip boom mic. Unfortunately, it also has two features that don't stack up against the Plantronics: a poorly placed answer/hang-up button and a wonky volume control.The Great:The one and only thing I hate about my Plantronics Voyager is the on-off mechanic. It requires me to locate a smallish button behind my ear, and press & hold for several seconds. The Jabra, on the other hand, has a flip-mic that is so much faster and more intuitive. The Jabra's earpiece also extends and retracts to find just the right height for maximum comfort. I was initially worried that the earpiece would move around on its own, but the connection is pretty stiff, which means it stays put where I want it. Between the custom-fit and light weight, I can wear this headset all day without noticing it.The Not-So-Great:One downside to the Jabra is a very large call button that fills the entire space on the outside of the earpiece. Unfortunately, this translates into accidental hang-ups if I try to adjust the earpiece during a call. The other nuisance with the Jabra is a touch-sensitive "swipe" volume control. Rather than push buttons or a rocker switch to adjust the volume, you must swipe your finger up or down across the spine of the headset. I'm sure some engineer thought himself very clever for coming up with the theory, but it's a nightmare in practise. I learned quickly that I'm better off reaching for my phone to adjust the call volume.In spite of these minor annoyances, the Jabra Motion is actually becoming my favourite headset. The light weight, custom comfort, and flip-mic happen to be the details that are most important to me. However, at roughly $130 as of this writing, it's hard for me to recommend the Jabra to other buyers when the Plantronics VoyagerPRO+,Pro HD, andLegendare just as good, but closer to $70-80 each. And, for bargain shoppers who don't need the latest-greatest, you just can't beat the value-pricedMotorola HX550for only about $30.

    Rating: 4

    2013-06-21: Important things for a headset (in my opinion):Set-up: Pretty simple to pair with both my cell phone and my computer. In actual use, it took me a bit to get down the call answer/hang-up/make call functions but it is like driving a stick shift- after a brief break-in, you'll be able to manage calls without thinking too hard about it. I like the motion sensor call pick up (and call pick up when you unfold the boom). I cannot comment on dual pairing with two phones but I know others have had issues with it. I actually like the big button but have learned how to adjust the headset on my ear without hanging up on people.Fit/Comfort: I like the behind-the-ear style as I am not fumbling with it like my motorola that I just stick in my ear. I feel secure enough I can go walking, horsebackriding, etc. and the thing stays put. For me this is a comfortable model, which is important to me. I've tried several hands free sets and this is definately one of the more comfortable sets I've used. I know other reviewers have had issues so that may be a deal-breaker for some purchasers. Obviously one size does not fit all when it comes to ear pieces. The positive is you can count on Amazon for an easy return if this doesn't fit you properly.Sound: Excellent sound, even in crowded places. I guess that is attributable to the noise reduction feature. I think it is excellent. Aside from incoming, outgoing is great, too. I have had any complaits from people I've called to 'speak up' or 'can you repeat that?'- even when I am outside and t is breezy or there is alot of ambient noise. It has a boom microphone and I think the audio on this piece really is superior.Battery life: shorter than some sets but I would guess that the noise reduction and audio input draw a bit more on the battery. It does have a long life when not being used.Volume control: the headset uses a swipe function for raising the volume. This can be a pain but you can either get used to it or adjust from your phone.I do not wear glasses so I cannot comment on that issue- for those who do, an around-the-ear design may not be the ideal style.The voice control is 'meh' but that is not a significant feature to me. If it is to you, you might want to try it out and see if you have success with using the voice control options.Overall, a great little headset that looks sleek and is relatively easy to use with great audio and comfort. I definitely found it better than my motorola which was actually more expensive. I recommend for those who can wear comfortably and deal with the brief learning curve to access the headsets functions. I'm very happy with mine!

    Rating: 4

    2013-05-14: Jabra is consistently a good bluetooth headset maker. Right up there with Plantronics. This Jabra Motion is no exception and is a great bluetooth headset. Build quality seems to be good and not as cheap as some other bluetooth headsets from other manufacturers. The boom mike flips back and forth smoothly. Pairing with my Samsung Note 2 was a breeze. The headset has the typical adjustments with ear gels and other adjustments to make this a comfortable fit. It is one of the more comfortable headsets I have owned.But onto the most important thing, how does it perform. From my usage it has performed great! Sound quality is excellent and I have had people on the other end who say they can't tell I'm on a bluetooth headset. It also adjusts the volume automatically based on your environment and it can be a noticeable different although not all the time. I have never had any trouble hearing people I am talking too. Overall sound quality and volume have been excellent.The other nice feature I like is the A2DP streaming. That means I can stream music from things like Spotify on my phone right to the earpiece and listen to music. While the sound won't be as good as headphones it is a great option. Overall I am very happy with this headset and would recommend it. The only con is I wish it was a little cheaper but then again you get what you pay for!

    Rating: 5

    2013-05-14: I haven't used a bluetooth headset before so (a) I don't have anything else to compare this device to and (b) when I encounter issues, I can't be sure if it's a headset issue, a paired device issue, or a user issue.That said, I like the headset. I didn't find it so intuitive that I didn't need to use the operating manual (some Amazon reviews have been helpful as well), but it's not too tricky to pair the headset. I've successfully paired it to a Samsung Android phone, an iPod Touch, a Mac Mini, and a MacBook Air. My biggest issue has been that the headset seems to struggle to switch back and forth between these different devices - I often just re-start the pairing process to ensure things happen smoothly and fairly quickly.Sound and mic quality seem comparable to other wired head-sets that I've used - quite adequate. It charges fairly quickly from a micro-USB charger, and it seems to hold a charge pretty well.The headset is nice and light, and it fits comfortably in my ear. Because it comes with three different sized silicone gel ear pieces, I bet it will fit in your ear too.Two complaints about the control:1 - the volume control is a touch dial on the back of the headset, right behind your ear. The location is good, but it takes a number of strokes up (or down) to turn the volume up (or down).2 - the button you use the most (to answer, to hang-up, to connect, etc) is right on the ear-piece; it's easy to bump when you're trying to adjust the piece in your ear.Overall...pretty good.

    Rating: 4

    2013-05-12: What I liked: Easy to pair to my iPhone, the voice commands (including answer and ignore - although someone said in a previous review you could not do this, you can), and the fact that the Jabra announces the caller's name. The sound quality was good.What I didn't like: It was too large for my ears, even with smallest ear plugs. However, I have this problem with all earpieces. I didn't like how you have to turn the volume up and down. I don't like that you have to go online to get a manual. Yes, it wasn't too hard to find, but it would have been nice to have a Quick Set Up sheet at least. And it's out of stock and has been for a while. How can you recommend something that has been out of stock for weeks?All in all a good product, but can you get something just as good for a cheaper prices? And now instead of who knows when?

    2013-04-24: I have been using headsets for my cell phone for at least 6 years, and most of them have been Jabra. This is the best Jabra I have used, though at the end of the day I would recommend a different product - theBose Bluetooth Headset Series 2 - Right Earwhich I have been using for the past 4 months and have been very satisfied with.Pros of the Jabra:-Pairing is greatly simplified over previous models. Voice prompts from the headset walk you through the process, give you the pin number required, and tells you when you are successful. (better than Bose)-The quality of the sound you hear is very good (as good for the most part as Bose)-I made a bunch of calls with this headset and the people I called all said the voice quality was very good (comparable to the Bose)-This Jabra is somewhat adjustable. You can extend the earphone boom a bit, which may help some people get a bit better fit (Bose is small and other than offering 3 different sized earbuds, does not adjust)-The volume controls are well placed (better than Bose)Cons of the Jabra:-There is one button for answering the phone, and it is in a bad place. I found myself repeatedly hitting it every time I adjusted the fit of the headset. It caused me to drop a couple of calls. I would get used to it eventually I guess but I'm sure that I will continue to at least occasionally hit this button unintentionally. (not nearly as good as Bose)-The big issue is comfort. I wear my headset all day at work. TheBose Bluetooth Headset Series 2 - Right Earis so comfortable that I often forget that I am wearing it. The Jabra on the other hand caused some irritation within the first hour and I had to give my ear a break before using it again.Furthermore the sound quality of the Bose was at least as good while indoors as the Jabra. I have not tried a comparison outdoors in windy conditions yet but that's not how I tend to use my headset.Verdict:Normally Bose products come at a huge price premium. In this case, the Bose is only slightly more expensive than the Jabra. Considering the significant difference in comfort, it's an easy decision - Bose.I did find one use that the Jabra is clearly superior for - long distance bike riding. I sometimes go on multi-hour bike rides, either in the gym or on bike trails near home. I sometimes need to stop and take a call - the Jabra outperforms the Bose in this case as its design makes it cling more securely to your ear than the Bose.

    2013-05-01: The Jabra Bluetooth device works well. It was easy to get connected to my phone. I've used it in both the right and left ears and the adjustments work well.     Rating: 5

    2013-04-29: I usually despise the headsets that attach only to the ear, finding that they make my ear sore and tender, continually irritating with a poor fit. In addition, I found that people had a hard time hearing me, as well as the controls being frustrating and out of my line of sight. Because of this, I almost always used the larger and more obvious over-the-head units with a boom mic. Hardly discrete for wearing as one shopped, etc. In addition, since these sets were usually wired, it meant that when our granddaughter was with us, the wire was a continual distraction as she tried to grab and pull it, further making it annoying.This headset is wonderful! It doesn't irritate my ear at any point, and adjusts enough to accommodate my ear size. I can hear clearly, and everyone is able to hear me clearly. The on/off is simple too, as is picking up a call, pairing with the phone OR the computer, and it works just fine with Skype as well. It was a bit trickier to pair with the computer than it was the phone, but it was still do-able. While the sound via telephone was reported by the call recipient as crystal clear and undistorted, call recipients via Skype said there was some "tin can" effect. In comparison to a wired headset with noise cancelling, this one does pick up more of the background sounds and transmits those as well, but remains within the realm of "acceptable" but a detail to remember if you happen to be one who is prone to fidgeting while on the phone (tapping, keyboard sounds, etc. were all picked up) Like other bluetooth devices, it is also sensitive to the operation of other electrical items in its vicinity although the call recipient did not hear the same distortion that I did (washing machine motor was our test).My prior experience with Jabra headsets had all been in the low end of their price spread, and this one far exceeds those, as well as exceeds the performance of other brands of headsets in similar price range as where this one is currently priced by Amazon. It's also the best performance I've ever experienced with any bluetooth headset. I can't say whether it would perform well in high noise environments such as diesel truck motors, plant noises, traffic, etc. as I am rarely in that type of location when trying to use a headset.Another great feature is that the device tells you exactly how much talk time is left on it--no more worries about when the battery is going to give out. With talk time in excess of six hours, it should last for almost anyone throughout an entire day.Overall, this is the best headset I've ever tried, and I'm very pleased with its performance. It's comfortable to wear, has good battery life, good sound, a good microphone, and is reliable in its performance. The only question I have is what the overall durability will be. I've had a number of devices begin to fail after a month or so. I'll update the durability when it does begin to fail. After all, nothing lasts forever!

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-01: Best experience is your own. I received it on time, every function works as intended. I have a HTC ONE so it has NFC and bluetooth 4.0. NFC syncing was smooth and enjoyable.
