    Rating: 5

    2013-05-21: I have owned several noise canceling headsets from Jawbone, Plantronics and now Jabra. My needs and expectations are very simple. The obvious, of course, is clear voice reproduction on both ends. I want it to fit comfortably and want the basic functions to be simple to understand and easy to access. I want the bluetooth pairing to happen easily without frustration. But the one area that seems the most simple to engineer but has been the most elusive is simply that it has enough volume. That seems to always be the detail that consistently falls short. What would remedy that problem in most any headset is simply that the earpiece has a snug, secure fit and it extends into the inner ear canal so that sound has an undistracted path to follow. Our individual outer ears are almost as unique as our fingerprints and so there is no one-size-fits-all solution. Most manufacturers include several sizes of plastic or foam to snap on and provide the best fit for our unique contours. This Jabra is not perfect, but to date it has the best fit and so I don't need to strain to hear my caller, especially when I'm driving. If my Plantronics Voyager only fit better, I believe it would slightly edge out the Jabra. But because the fit and volume are superior, at least for me, Jabra Motion is now my go to headset. One feature I like as well is that to turn it off, you simply angle in the beam that holds the microphone. That prevents draining the battery when not in use. I like the touch sensitive area that allows me to increase or decrease the volume by just brushing my finger up or down. I prefer that to fishing for a button that then requires a push, which can dislodge it's fit. The noise canceling works great. To test it I walked gradually closer to a huge floor fan and the caller noticed no change in voice clarity and heard no noise. Very impressive. You can't go wrong with Plantronics, arguably the leaders of the headset industry. But for now, this Jabra Motion has become my favorite.

    Rating: 4

    2013-04-27: This is a pretty decent bluetooth headset. Setup is a BREEZE, as soon as you are done charging it, the bluetooth device actually talks you through on getting things set up. I like the little notifications it will give on occasion, such as how much talk-time battery remains. The sound is great and I haven't had anybody complain so far of being unable to hear me. I haven't even had anybody guess I was on a bluetooth, which is encouraging. The call quality on the receiving end is also great! There aren't a lot of controls, which are good and bad. Personally, I prefer working the controls on my phone, but I know a lot of people prefer them on the device itself. Volume and answer is all I need, and that is what comes with this. I prefer less controls so I'm not accidentally hitting the wrong buttons, so this works best for me.My only complaint is comfort. Because it sits on the top of your ears it takes a while to get used to it for prolonged periods of time. The first time I put it on I almost yanked it off swearing to never wear it again. After playing with it for a while I got somewhat comfortable with it, but then I started noticing it a few hours later. I've yet to get through an entire day without becoming annoyed with it at one point or another. Taking it off for a break is often welcomed.Overall, Jabra makes great headsets and this isn't an exception.

    Rating: 4

    2013-05-15: Before writing this review I used Jabra MOTION paired with an iPhone 5 for 30 days. I found the Jabra to be a solid performing headset but it fell short when compared to thePlantronics M50 - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Blackwhich is 1/4 the price. Range, clarity, battery life, and usability are all excellent with the Jabra. Due to its larger size however, the headset can sometimes be difficult to secure to your ear and it feels heavy compared to similar devices. The volume button is also difficult to use, as well as the mute button, which duplicates your phone's mute function and can be confusing. Voice prompts are exceptional and when you turn the device on, it tells you the hours of remaining battery life. I noticed no material improvements with the "motion" technology that supposedly improves mic performance when you're in motion.Size:My biggest complaint with the Jabra is its large size. Unlike the Plantronics M50 which has a fairly small footprint, the Jabra is very noticeable by others and awkward to use in public. Also, when folded for storage, the Jabra is much larger in your pocket than similar devices. For this reason, I use it exclusively in my office.Sound Quality and Range:The Jabra's sound quality is exceptional. Jabra maintains a reliable connection for twice the distance of the Plantronics M50. The Jabra's larger battery probably allows is to consume more power, so you can definitely expect more range than smaller devices. Also, during my 30 days of initial use, I never experienced connection problems between the headset and phone.Ease of Use:The Jabra is easy to use but as mentioned above, the volume and mute controls are confusing. The volume control is difficult to operate and lacks tactile feedback. The mute control duplicates that of your phone's - for example, if you mute your phone and the headset, you need to un-mute both to talk. To avoid confusion, I only used the mute function on my phone.Overall Rating:I like the Jabra MOTION headset. However, when compared to the Plantronics M50, the Jabra falls short mainly on price and size. All other features like sound quality and battery life between the two devices are comparable. For this reason, it's difficult to highly recommend the Jabra over other options. If you're looking for a large battery and excellent range, this headset might be worth the extra cost.

    Rating: 4

    2013-04-20: Premium quality Bluetooth headsets keep getting better and better. I've been using them for years as my job requires talking to customers on the phone constantly, often in crowded or noisy places like airports. I've discovered that for the serious business user, you need a boom microphone - the ultra small headsets just don't work. For that reason, I've been less than satisfied with some of the smaller offers from Jabra in the past, and I keep coming back to the Plantronics Voyager line. I used a Voyager 510 years ago, and today use aPlantronics Voyager Legend Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black(though I've tried many other earpieces in the middle).It's hard to review a headset in isolation, so I will compare this to my headset of choice, the Plantronics Voyager Legend. Cutting to my conclusion, I will say that while Jabra got much right with the Motion, it has some serious shortcomings. I will go back to my Plantronics and do not recommend this headset, but as with all of my reviews, you need to decide for yourself. Some deal killers for me might not matter to you. Overall, the sound and clarity slightly exceed the Plantronics Voyager Legend, but the user features take it down in my mind. There are many good things to recommend this headset, just not in the areas of concern for me. Read each area and decide for yourself.Size and WeightThe Jabra Motion is very similar in size and weight to my Voyager Legend (actually a bit lighter at 6.1 oz), but instead of having a boom mic that extends from the speaker, the boom mic extends from the bottom of the earpiece itself. The microphone flips up for storage. Flipping it down will automatically answer a call, as will placing the earpiece on your ear.ComfortAs seems to be standard today, the earpiece comes with a silicone gel ear insert pre-installed, with a smaller and a larger one in the box for different sized ears. I'm a medium kind of guy, so the medium earpiece always works for me. The ear bud itself is on an extendable post so the height from the top of your ear to the bud can be adjusted. This is a really nice feature, but I found it didn't help the fit too much. I was able to get it on my ear and it feels reasonably snug, but the Plantronics Voyager Legend has a larger loop to go over the ear itself and seems to hold on better. Both are reasonably comfortable, but I found the Jabra didn't stay on quite as snugly. Your ear shape might be different from mine, but these were my experiences.ChargingOn the latest Plantronics Voyager Legend, I was quite disappointed that they switched from a standard micro-USB to a proprietary magnetic connector. They also only include a USB cable with a charger for AC wall voltage. Kudos to Jabra for sticking with a standard micro-USB connector, and also for including both a wall charger and a car charger! Charging this is a breeze.Battery LifeThis headset is fully compatible with the battery display on my iPhone, and it has an admirable 7 hours of talk time at full charge. When first connected, a voice tells you the talk time left. I just reviewed a pair ofJabra REVO Wireless Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black. Those must be made by a different team at Jabra because they do not tell you the time left. In terms of announcing battery life and the total battery life, these are quite comparable to my Plantronics Voyager Legend. Unlike the Plantronics Voyager Legend, Jabra does not have aPlantronics Voyager Legend Charge Case - Frustration-Free Packaging - Blackfor getting even longer battery life.Controls - PhysicalUnfortunately, this is where the headset really fell down in my mind. If I could pick one reason I can't use it, it would be the large "answer" button on the outside surface of the ear bud. If you try to push your finger against the ear piece to make it fit more snugly in your ear, you automatically push the "answer/hangup" button. Plantronics put this button on the back surface of the ear bud, so you did not accidentally hit it when you pushed it into your ear. Jabra made the button huge and put it right on the outside surface. I have already hung up on people twice when I went to push the earpiece into my ear better. This is unacceptable, and just poor design in my mind. Also, if you click the button twice you "ignore" the call, and I've found myself doing that as well.The volume control was also not well executed. It does adjust volume via Bluetooth and not locally on the headset (a good feature), but it is a touch dial which takes quite a bit of pushing to activate. Sliding your finger top to bottom does not give you continuous volume control. You have to slide your finger over the entire control to drop or raise the volume by 1 "setting". So going to full volume from quiet can take more than 5 full swipes over the ear, and sometimes it doesn't register and you have to reswipe.I did like the mute control on the end of the boom microphone. It is nice to have a true mute button on a headset (Plantronics has similar)Controls - VoiceThere is a voice control which you can activate when off a call by pushing the "mute" button. From there you can voice dial, and this seemed to work reasonably well. However, the Plantronics added a voice control to "answer" or "ignore" calls. I've gotten so used to this feature that I can't believe Jabra doesn't have it. It is quite convenient to answer when your arms are full, and I am surprised that the voice control here lacks this feature.BluetoothPairing was fast, but the voice in the headset did not differentiate between Phone 1 (the iPhone 4) and Phone 2 (my iPad) when I paired them. Multipoint is extremely important to me, or the ability to switch quickly between two different devices. I found this headset got confused easily. Despite pairing to two devices successfully, it did not seem able to adeptly switch between them. Sometimes it would switch, sometimes it would crackle after the switch, and sometimes it wouldn't do anything. The Jabra Revo headphones I have do a great job, so perhaps that team can help their coworkers out. Lacking decent multipoint support is a tough sell for me when buying a new headset.DocumentationToo many electronics manufacturers are now relying on online manuals. I get this for less expensive tools, but for $130, don't tell me to go online to learn how to use NFC pairing. There's also no list of voice commands in the manual - you need to ask the headset to tell you the voice commands. The navigation voice in the headset itself is creepy. It's odd, because once again my Jabra Revo headphones have a nice voice.Sound Quality and Noise CancellationIt may sound strange that I saved this for the end of the review, but honestly I have found that the major headset manufacturers seem to have converged on good high end designs that do the job they need to do. The sound was crisp and loud in my ear piece, and everyone I called said I sounded wonderful. Background noise was effectively canceled and my conversations were crisp and clear. In fact, it seemed a bit better than my Plantronics Voyager Legend, but honestly, both are excellent devices as far as sound quality is concerned.My conclusion? I gave my Plantronics headset of choice just 4 stars because it had some issues preventing it from being 5 stars. I was going to rate this Jabra Motion 3 stars because it is a good headset, just not as good as very similar market competitor. Upon further consideration, I think it deserves 4 stars. Just like the Plantronics, it is not perfect, but it is a good headset that just doesn't fit my needs due to the fit on the head and the large sized hang-up button on the outside surface. I hope my review was helpful - this headset might be for you, but it just really wasn't for me.

    Rating: 4

    2013-05-13: Summary: This is a great bluetooth earpiece. Its around the back fit is unique and comfortable, and its contoured earpiece is great for fit and noise blocking. I have tried this as well as aPlantronics Voyager, aJawbone ERA, and aJawbone ICON. On balance, this is my favorite, but they're all close enough that it's going to come down to personal preference. I'll try to break down the differences to help you chose, but IMHO you're best off checking out a store where you can try them out.Sound Performance: A tie, with the slight edge to the Motion on noise blocking. I'm not an audiophile, but all of the earpieces have great sound. They're all mono, but sounds are rich enough to listen to music in a pinch, and are great for calls, podcasts, etc. I do think that the Motion's contoured earpiece (it's shaped like the inside of your ear and fits a little more snugly) blocks out exterior sound from the ear it's in a little better than the other three, which I appreciate). All four oversell their noise cancellation slightly, IMHO. With all of them, I can make a call with the car radio on and the earpiece cancel most but not all of the radio sound. Calls in light wind are fine with all four, but heavy wind gets choppy.Bluetooth Performance: The Motion has been a little buggy with my iPhone 4s. Most of the time it's fine - the call button activates Siri, it answers and hangs up fine, but occasionally some of my apps sporadically fail to recognize the earpiece. It shows up as a choice of output devices, but the sound just won't play unless I reconnect by turning the earpiece off and back on. I haven't had this issue with any of the other earpieces, but it's not a major issue and might get fixed in firmware update.Fit: I think the Motion wins on fit, with the Voyager coming in second. The around the ear design plus a contoured earpiece produces a very comfortable, stable fit. The Jawbone earpieces are small enough that they are designed to fit mostly through friction (although they do come with optional earloops).Battery and charging: The Motion is the overall winner in this category, IMHO. Its bigger body gives it longer performance than the Jawbone earpieces, and I appreciate that it has a micro-usb charging port, which lets me use a variety of easily available charging cables or adapters. (Jawbone is also micro-B, but the Plantronics uses a non-standard magnetic cable that is very cool, but that I don't personally like because I'd like all my devices to use the same cable).Style: This is a matter of personal preference, I think the Jawbones look the coolest. They're the smallest and also the most stylish, so they win on both appearance fronts. (Especially the Icon, which is tiny). This looks cool in kind of a sci-fi way, though, so it's not bad.Design: This has a lot of features. If you lift the boom on the front it turns off, or you can drop the boom to turn it on or answer calls. There's a "call/answer/hangup button" on the outside of the ear column, and a "mute/voice control" button on the end of the boom. Some reviewers report problems with accidentally hanging up on calls, but I haven't had that problem.Brains: I'm not a great reviewer for the high-end brains of these things, and apologize for that. The Motion has all kinds of voice commands, and you can download apps to customize various settings, like whether or not an LED shows when you are on the phone. Check out the other reviews to see what other people think about that.Price: The prices will vary, so I'll let you compare those yourself. The Icon is a generation or two old, so it will probably be a lot cheaper, but the others should be comparable.Conclusion: The new high end earpieces are close enough that choosing one is going to be a matter of personal preference. After trying four of them out pretty extensively, I slightly prefer the Motion, but definitely try them out yourself and see.

    Rating: 4

    2013-05-07: I have used several Jabra headsets over the years, and, by far, the JABRA MOTION BLUETOOTH MONO HEADSET is my favorite! First of all, the pairing was the easiest of any bluetooth device I have ever paired. You just charge the headset, turn it on, put it in your ear, the voice tells you to go here, here, here on your phone, and voila! Your headset is paired to your phone in just seconds!Second, the JABRA MOTION BLUETOOTH MONO HEADSET has a nice clear sound in both directions. In my ear, voices are clear and fairly true; I have no problems understanding anyone. With my friends, family, and coworks that I have asked, my voice is clear and easy to hear...none of that "in an echo chamber" effect that everyone hates so much.Third, the noise cancellation works very well. With my test subjects, I tried getting ice out of the refrigerator door, using the blender, clinking dishes as they were removed from the diswasher, and loud, interupting children. Almost all of the noise was removed; I had one person who thought they heard crinkling paper, but that was really the ice dispenser! So, I would definitely say that the JABRA MOTION BLUETOOTH MONO HEADSET noise cancellation feature is excellent.Fourth, the fit. The JABRA MOTION BLUETOOTH MONO HEADSET comes with earbuds in three sizes; the smallest works best for me. I love the over the ear design to keep it firmly in place. The style were you just push it into your ear like Lieutenant Uhura's ear piece drive me nuts and always fall out. Overall, the JABRA MOTION BLUETOOTH MONO HEADSET is light weight and comfortable. You can actually forget you have it on.Fifth, the JABRA MOTION BLUETOOTH MONO HEADSET has a good, long batter life inbetween charges. After changing fully, the nice lady in your ear will tell you that you have 7 hours of talk time. I work from home and am on the phone all day long. Not having to remember to recharge the headset between meeings is a vast improvement over previous Jabra headsets.Sixth, the contols are obvious and easy to use. You don't need any divine inspiration to figure them out. I like that in a headset.So, there you have it. My six top reasons of why you should try the JABRA MOTION BLUETOOTH MONO HEADSET. After trying several dozen headsets over the years, both wired and wireless, IMHO, the JABRA MOTION BLUETOOTH MONO HEADSET tops them all.FYI: here is what comes in the Box: Headset, charger, usb cord, car charger attachment, extra ear buds (large, medium, and small), and really good instructions. Pretty much everything you need.

    Rating: 5

    2013-04-25: Let the games marvelous headset games. If your anything like me, you've had just about every make headset. I've had them all, we all have. Some better than others but I've never found one that I was in love with. Since then I've tried dozens upon dozens of different Bluetooth headsets; they have ranged from great to mediocre to downright bad. I have found that the "great" Bluetooth headsets I've used have consistently come from one of two companies - Jabra or Plantronics. So here comes the Jabra motion. The Jabra Motion looked pretty in its clear plastic shell; so pretty that I felt a little bit bad about freeing it from its box. Once completely unboxed however, I was pleased to see that the device not only looked good but seemed to be thoughtfully designed as well. It returns to the "curve around the ear design" which works for many people. The design of the Jabra Motion headset is important, since the best Bluetooth headsets are ones you can comfortably wear throughout the day. You know, the Bluetooth headsets you don't feel the need to take on and off, and that don't cause "ear fatigue" because of the pressure they put on some portion of your ear or head. This Headset is amazingly comfortable and stands out in that respect. This surprised me since it is rather large, and it literally wraps around your ear. This headset is bigger than many of the headsets I've owned in recent years -- along with the excellent design -- allows for the proper distribution of weight. The result is a headset that sits comfortably on your ear without placing too much pressure on any one spot. Add in the fact that the earpiece not only swivels and allows you to use the headset on either the left or the right ear, but it also has a movable post so that you can adjust the height of the portion that sits in your ear, and you now have a headset that offers as close to a custom fit as you're going to find without it being a custom fit. I have been wearing this headset as much as possible since it arrived last week, so I could test its comfort over extended periods of use; I have to say that it is one of the most comfortable headsets I have ever used.SETTING UP THE JABRA MOTIONJabra recommends charging the device fully before using it for the first time. After an hour and a half the battery icon glowed green and the Motion was ready for pairing. A fully charged battery should yield six hours of uninterrupted use and a depleted battery will only take two hours to fully recharge.Pairing the headset to my phone was effortless. Upon folding down the descriptively named "boom-arm," the headset came to life. It was just a moment before the reason behind the user's manual thinness was revealed: all of the instructions are presented in audio form through the earbud when the Motion is turned on for the first time. I disregarded the instructions on how to pair the headset via Bluetooth because I wanted to utilize Jabra's newly implemented NFC (near-field communication) technology support. All I had to do was physically touch the Motion to the back of my NFC enabled smart phone (the Samsung Galaxy S3) and a moment later I received confirmation that the two had paired. It was perhaps the most painless pairing process I've ever encountered. Pairing the Motion to my computer required the usual authentication process, yet was made easier by the audio instructions.So how is the audio quality on the Jabra Motion Headset? In a word it's fantastic. Yes, I said it FFFAAANNNTTTAAASSSTIC. I'm not using the word lightly. I just spent some time on the phone while driving to and walking around New York City and I've asked people who I'm talking to how the headset sounds. They have used words like "amazing" and "fantastic". Yes, while driving with the windows closed the connection was perfect and it didn't sound like I was using a headset at all. That was true even when I was speaking in a whisper. Things changed a bit when I opened the window and let the wind rush by my head while driving at about 65 miles an hour. But the worst it got was, "Now it sounds like you are on any headset." That means that with the window opens at 60 miles an hour the Jabra Motion Bluetooth Headset was as good or better than most Bluetooth headsets are in a quiet room. That's rather impressive.All this held true on my end of the conversation as well, and while I know I'm sounding a bit too enthusiastic I honestly can't help it - this headset sounds better than any headset I have ever used. I also used the headset to access Siri and to do voice recognition on my iPhone. The convenience of activating Siri by simply touching the headset was great, and the accuracy of the voice-to-text transcription was as good as I have seen. That tells me that the audio signal the phone is receiving from the headset is clean and crisp, and it vastly improves the ability to text by voice on the fly.This is the best headset I've ever used. I'm planning on purchasing 1 for my wife and one for the house phone. This is a must have for anyone using a headset.

    Rating: 5

    2013-04-24: Wow. This is really something else. The real test of a blue tooth set is how you sound to other and they sound to you. This passes the "I had no idea you were on a Bluetooth headset" test! The sound is clear and completely noise-free! I don't like headsets, they usually bug my ear. What this tells me is that you get your money's worth with Bluetooth headsets, because this may be pricey, but is really the best headset I have ever used.

    2013-04-27: I always loved Jabra wired earphones back when I had PDA's, so I was very hopeful when this arrived.The MOTION paired very easily with my iPhone and another cell phone. It includes three differntly-SHAPED tips for your ears, not just the usual differently-sized tips. When a call comes in, the Jabra announces the caller's name, a feature not found on thePlantronics Voyager Pro HD, a comparable high-end bluetooth set. Volume is easy to control, and call initiation and ending is simple, too.There are two big cons with this bluetooth, and they could be deal-breakers. The whole MOTION tends to fall off the ear if you move your head vigorously, even if you feel you have a good fit (the MOTION is light on the ear, but doesn't really grip the ear in any way). In a humorous demonstration I put the MOTION in one ear and thePlantronics Voyager Pro HDin the other, and pretended to be in a vigorous conversation; the Jabra went flying. Really, this just isn't what I want when I'm driving. The other problem with the MOTION is the lack of boom adjustability. There are two positions; open/on, and closed/off. Too bad about your beard, collar, or earrings!

    2013-05-08: My boyfriend has tried many headset options over the years, and he currently enjoys his Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset. We decided to test out this Jabra to see how it compared.First, the unit is fairly sizeable, especially compared with the H19txt. He uses the smallest size on the Jabra and even so he'd like to go smaller to have it fit properly. He's 5'10" so an average sized male. The silicon piece which hooks on and goes into the ear doesn't seal well - it sits on rather than in. So max volume isn't always loud enough, depending on the environment.It's reasonably comfortable to wear for multiple hours at a stretch. However when he does have to swap ears, it's not as easy as other devices. You have to pull out and rotate pieces, all while carefully avoiding the "call" button so it doesn't try to do something. The volume control is functional, but a little hokey. He'd prefer a typical rocker switch for more precise control.Given the price he was surprised at the less than 8 hour battery life. Also, the connection was a bit flaky. With other headsets, he had no problem listening to an audio book, having a call come in, taking the call, and going back to the book. With this headset the sequence would often disconnect the headset, requiring him to turn the headset off and on again to reconnect.It's also disconnected from the phone even though the phone's right there on his belt.On the up side the sound quality is fairly good. When he opens his car window, the headset adjusts and the call is still easy to hear on both ends. The mute function is a nice feature.So we'll give this a 3.5 stars given the disconnect issues. There's no reason we'd want to use this when the H19txt works so much better and is smaller.We received a review copy of this unit through the Amazon vine program.

    Rating: 4

    2013-05-14: The Jabra Motion Bluetooth headset with intelligent motion sensor technology, made in China, is designed to work with iOS and android Bluetooth enabled devices. Built in technologies include NFC pairing, an energy saving nap mode, noise blackout, and A2DP multimedia streaming. The battery lasts for up to seven hours of talk time or fifteen hours of standby time. multiple eargels and adjustable parts allow a personalized fit for every user. The CONNECT iOS and android app customizes your headset to provide the best experience.The package includes the Jabra motion headset, an ultimate comfort eargel, an AC charger, a car charger, and the quick start manual. Pairing was simple, and then required downloading apps for customizing. From then on, the headset connected effortlessly when turned on.Voice controls cover basic commands. For audio play back, I had to say "phone controls" to the Motion headset, then tell Siri to "play music." Other accepted phrases include redial, call back, battery, pair new device, and cancel. Pressing the call button during periods of inactivity will indicate if connected and the battery time left. Pressing the voice button and saying battery will only provide the latter information.I climb stairs in a building to train for a charity hike to Yosemite in June 2013, and decided to use the headset to listen to podcasts while going up and down the numerous flights. There were no issues to listening to the podcasts until my hair became sweaty. Any moisture falling from my hair onto the volume pad caused the volume to quickly decrease to mute. This isn't a situation I would consider to be normal, but it did point out a limitation if you plan on using the headset outdoors on a hot summer day.Then after two weeks of use, the Jabra Motion Bluetooth headset started to randomly and repeatedly turn off and on, typically several times a minute, for no apparent reason rendering the headset completely useless. I contacted Jabra by email and was told the problem was likely due to a Bluetooth communications error, and I needed to reset the Motion headset and reconnect it to the phone.To reset the Jabra Motion, I was told to make sure the unit was powered off. Then press and hold the CALL and VOICE buttons simultaneously, and extend the microphone arm without releasing the buttons. Keep pressing the buttons for a few seconds until the battery light powers on white / purple. Release the buttons and the headset will get into pairing mode automatically, ready to connect.After doing this several times with no resolution, I contacted Jabra again. This time I received no response. Since I am required to submit Amazon Vine reviews within a short time period of receiving an item, I'm unable to pursue resolution any further to remain in compliance. The product has failed, and Jabra has not responded to a request for assistance at any time in the last week. If you're looking for a quality Bluetooth headset backed by a company ready to offer support, look elsewhere.PROS:Listen to music with A2DP multimedia streamingNoise blackout, dual microphones, and app aid in clearer communications1 year warrantyCONS:No direct voice commands to control audioFailed after two weeksJabra support unresponsive

One asked if I was in some kind of storm, another if a low-flying plane was going by.I liked the shape, the ease of setting it up, everything about it. But if people can't make me out clearly, that is a deal breaker.

    2013-04-30: Further update: The noise cancelling works great. I love being able to listen to audio books, too. The more I use this, the more I like it. If I were to lose it, I would buy another, immediately.Updating, after using this headset for a week, I am even more impressed. It works well outside in the wind. After the next convention, I will revise this review. I love the sound.

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-15: I had a Jawbone and loved it but without a specially made earpiece it was difficult to fit my ear. The Jabra motion has provided equal of better sound quality but also added in other capabilities.

    Rating: 5

    2013-05-19: I spend many hours each day on a bluetooth headset (yes, I am that person). I found the sound quality of the Jabra motion to be quite good, comparable to my Plantronics Voyager. This headset has a few quirks that will keep it from being my "go to" headset:Too easy to disconnect a call unintentionally -- the large button on the outside of the earpiece makes it much too easy to accidentally disconnect callsDoes not stay well seated on my ear -- this headset never feels like it's completely settled and it is very easy to shake it off my earthe Motion controls -- I keep a headset on for hours. If I'm sitting still typing this headset will go on and off (and tell me about it!) repeatedly. It's quite annoying actuallyPairing -- while it pairs easily, it seems to drop the pair equally easilyUnadjustable boom -- this is a female problem but the boom interferes with many of my earrings.

    Rating: 3

    2013-05-16: Getting right to the point, I own a Bose Bluetooth Series 2 and this Jabra MOTION. I prefer the Bose for sound quality, comfort, and looks. The Jabra isn't bad. No, I am not a Bose enthusiast, but I truly prefer Bose in this case.

    Rating: 4

    2013-05-13: I am a heavy user of bluetooth headsets. Use the headsets extensively (several hours/day) for work and whenever talking while driving. I've have tested many bluetooth headsets and currently use thePlantronics Voyager Proheadset.This headset meets and passes my primary requirement... the microphone and speaker quality is good. Hard to believe how many other headsets can't live up to the basic requirement for microphone/speaker quality.Other notable shining points... the headset fits my ear and is comfortable (once I figured out the process for putting it on, very different than my current headset), the volume is good, I very much like the folding boom to turn off the headset for carrying in my pocket (massive positive that you don't get butt dials this way). Also, when charging, it is very clear when it is done.Because of the positives, this headset enters the limited category of 2 headsets that I can live with (out of many that I have tried)... this one (the Jabra Motion) and the Plantronics Voyager.I gave the Jabra Motion 4 stars because there are some notable areas for improvement (and didn't give it 3 stars because, even with the annoyances, this is a nice headset... it's just that it can be so much better).Concerns:- Glitches waking up. While using the headset, if leaving it in my ear without turning it off (folding the boom), it seems to go to sleep. If I receive a call... it doesn't always wake up properly and answer the call. I am forced to fold and unfold the boom to reliably pick up a call on my iPhone 4s.- The button on the headset to pickup/hangup/redial is very easy to bump when adjusting the headset in my ear. I got tired of thinking "arrrgh, I did it again" when adjusting the headset- Volume control is gimmicky. It is a touch sensor that I did not like at all. My hair would constantly get it the way of using it.- Mobile app for the phone... limited use, waste of time. Nothing worse than an app the provides almost no value.Missed Opportunity with the Mobile App:I think Jabra missed an great opportunity with their mobile app for the headset. The limited use functionality that it has is a waste of time to spend downloading. However, the opportunity is to add the ability to tweak all kinds of features I would love love LOVE to be able to tweak... for example. Turn off double-click re-dialing. That feature is a bane for me... hate it in all headsets and would like it to go away. So, set a feature in the app to default to it on and let me undo it. Same thing for other features... give me the ability to set a default power-up volume. So, if I adjust the volume in a noisy or quiet environment, and later use the headset, it goes back to what I want it to be. I'm sure with a little thought, a whole slew of options would come to light. Develop an app that improves my use of this product... be a differentiator versus the waste of time that it is now.

    Rating: 4

    2013-04-25: As ridiculous as bluetooth headsets look--and can we all just admit they look very, very silly--and as annoying as those that wear them constantly can be, having one for in-car use is still fairly essential if you want to use your phone. Yes, you can pair your phone with (most) car sound systems, but shouting on speaker phone isn't really that awesome either. So, if you want/need to use your cellphone while driving your choices are A) look a psychotic talking to yourself and/or a self-important jerk by using a bluetooth headset or B) look like an equally crazy loon by shouting yourself hoarse and over again and banging your head on the steering wheel when the person on the other end of the line asks you to repeat yourself for the third time with a speakerphone. Or maybe all of the above is just me ...So, having established a bluetooth headset as a necessary at times, but not necessarily welcome evil, I tried out the Jabra Motion. First and foremost, I found it almost instantly uncomfortable. The way it fit over my ear and the size of the bud that goes into your ear. I liked both those elements a lot less than the Plantronics I've used. For my husband, it wasn't as noticeably "pinchy" so your mileage may vary. The weight was about the norm for these sorts of units and I didn't fit it either enviably light, or oppressively heavy.In terms of sound quality I found this good, to very good. I had no trouble hearing callers, or having them hear me ... Or at least no more trouble than is normal via cell phone. Ending calls was a little spotty, but I think that's more just a matter of getting used to the headset and the button's placement and how hard you have to press. The volume though is really poorly located and activated. I basically had to take it off in order to adjust and then, if it wasn't right, take it off and try again. Annoying.My other gripe is that the large in-ear portion fit so tightly that it definitely effected my hearing when it was in, so it's not the type of thing I'd like to leave on and, as annoying as it is to put on, I hate to fiddle with taking something on/off to answer the phone or make a call. That's a huge drawback in my book.As for pairing, it was quick, easy and successful with by my and my husband's iPhones (4s and 5, respectively), so no dings there. And, all in all, this worked pretty well.Overall, though I hate to give wishy-washy advice, I think the most important thing about a bluetooth headset, since sound quality has sort of stabilized across the board at this point, is how comfortable it is to YOU. What I find great, you might awful, and vice versa. I'd encourage everyone to try a few one before committing to one brand. Otherwise, it's kind of a trial and error process.

    Rating: 3

    2013-06-19: This is a decent headset, the noise cancellation is quite good, never got a single complaint, battery life is good as well. Sadly the headset fails on several levels:1. The call button is placed on the ear piece which will you'll be adjusting constantly. I've made numerous accidental calls fidgeting with the placement of the ear piece.2. When connecting the headset to my iPhone it insisted I download two apps-- one of which required a registration key which was not included in the box. I don't think that app was actually supposed to be used with this headset.3. The headset had some weird distortion at times which seemed to be unrelated to distance from the phone. I looked for a firmware update to fix the issue but no such luck. Could not recommend headset until such time as this is fixed.

    Rating: 2

    2013-06-08: I regularly use a BlueAnt headset and thus compare any new headsets to my tested and trusted one. I'm not impressed with Jabra MOTION and here's why:- the fit leaves much to be desired. It kept falling out of my ear even with repeated attempts to get it to "sit" right- I had no trouble pairing it with my phone, but I did have trouble with keeping the phone paired- I attempted to use the voice commands to answer calls with no success- I tried using it in the airport and the "adjust to motion and environment" function was non-existent

    Rating: 3

    2013-04-30: The two are similar in physical design, but there are huge differences in the details. The Motion is much more expensive, but in my opinion, the Jabra MOTION blows the WAVE out of the water.Key differences:More comfortable - The MOTION's earpiece can rotate on it's shaft and can slide up and down to adjust for different ear sizes. The WAVE's earpiece is on a flexible shaft, but the distance between the earpiece and the top-of-the-ear curve is fixed.More Functions - The Motion has a number of voice-activated commands while the Wave is your basic earphone.Much better fidelity - There's no comparison when listening to music through the two headsets. The Motion sounds good. The Wave is just this side of awful.Volume adjustment - The Motion has a panel that you slide your finger against. The Wave has a rocker switch.My conclusion...If the extra cost isn't a problem, buy the Motion. The Wave is still a good headset, but this is infinitely better.

    Rating: 5

    $B00D1RR52K

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2013-07-31: The VicTsing Data Sync Charging Cradle is a must have for anyone who has an iPhone 5. My iPhone 5 sits perfectly in the slot and I don't even have to remove it from its case.The cradle itself is really lightweight. It has four rubber feet that will keep it from sliding. It comes with a 5V micro USB cord. You can plug it into your computer USB port or a USB power adapter. The cradle can also be used to sync with your computer besides just for charging purposes.It has a very bright blue light up pencil/pen holder hole which is about the only negative comment I can say about this unit. I tried using it as a charger next to my nightstand but the bright blue lights surrounding the pencil/pen holder were just too bright and lit up the room at night. It would have been nice to have and on/off switch for the lights. I am using it at my office which is a perfect place because I am able to see incoming texts and calls because my iPhone 5 is on mute during office hours and use to lay flat on my desk, even when charging. Now I can have it charging and sitting straight up and not miss any important texts or phone calls from my family and friends. Now I can see it light up informing me when a call is coming in or an email or text has been received.I would of given it 5 stars but it loses one because of the bright blue light. I fixed the problem by putting a piece of black electrical tape over it. Overall, I really like it. My iPhone 5 slides easily in place, no connectivity issues and now I don't have to be constantly be checking my iPhone at work since it is looking straight at me!Sample provided for review purposes.

    Rating: 4

    2013-08-07: I use this charging station with my iPad mini in my office when I'm listing to my iHeartRadio app on it. I like to have talk news radio going throughout the day when I'm working and since my favorite radio station isn't local, I listen to it via my iPad mini using the radio application. What I like about this dock is it sits my iPad mini up on a stand, instead of it just laying down on my desk. It sits it up so I have a much better view of the screen and I can see navigate through my mini's menus easier.It charges my mini as well, so the battery doesn't drain all day while I'm listening to my station. Because of the location of the charging port on the mini, when it's plugged in for charging, the iPad mini sits vertically in the dock, not horizontally. There is a fun glowing spot on the back of the dock for holding my iPad's stylus, that lights up with the dock is plugged into a USB port to power it.The dock itself is done in both black and while colors, so it matches both black and while Apple products. There are four small rubber feet grips on the bottom of the dock, which helps keep it from sliding around on smooth surfaces. I think I like this dock better as an iPad mini dock than one for an iPhone, since it seems just the right size for the mini.A sample was provided for reviewing purposes.

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-08: Nothing fancy. It works fine but like anything else Apple, it works better with an Apple authorized lightening cable (it must say on the box "Designed for Apple".If I had to do it again, I would buy an alarm clock with docking station instead.

    Rating: 2

    2013-08-02: I was excited to see that VicTsing makes a true lightning connection to charge my iPhone 5. I had tried a similar Belkin dock and was disappointed that the lightning connection was too short to use with the phone in a case. Unfortunately, the same is true with the VicTsing. Even with a case with a wide cutout in the base, the lighting connection does not fully make contact with the port. No contact, no charging. The only case that worked for me was completely cut out in the bottom with not even a rim of plastic or silicone. VicTsing, like Belkin, could solve the problem with a longer connection and, for bare iPhones, an adapter to raise them as though they were in a case. Or they could otherwise allow the user to adjust the height.But on a bare iPhone 5, the dock works perfectly. There is no support behind it, however, and the connection has free play, so my phone wiggled back and forth while I was trying to plug it in or disconnect it. I suppose the semi-floating connection makes sure that the lightning connection doesn't snap off since there's is a gap behind the phone.The blue, lighted pen holder looks cool, although its function is questionable. I'd rather have a lightning connection that didn't require me to remove my phone from its case every time I wanted to charge it. (Note: I received a sample for review.)-- Debbie Lee Wesselmann

    Rating: 3

    2013-07-26: I've used this data sync cradle for the latest generation of iOS devices for a few days, and so far I have been really pleased with it. When Apple decided to ditch their old connector design, a lot of cradles became instantly obsolete. From what I understand Apple is also very cagey about licensing their new connector design to the third-party developers, all of which has resulted in a very scarce market for third party products. And this is what makes this VicTsing Data Sync Charging Cradle so valuable. It's an inexpensive and well-designed cradle that is up to date with the latest technology. It sits very nicely on your work desk or a side table. It works with iPhone 5, iPad Mini, or the latest iPad. However, I've only tested it with my iPad Mini. I was able to sync all of the photos my iPad Mini to my MacBook Air quickly and straightforwardly. The cradle uses the micro USB cable to connect to a computer or an external charger. Unfortunately, the cradle doesn't come with the charger itself. This is not that much of a problem for me as I've accumulated plenty of chargers over the years, but a new user might want to have this option available. Furthermore, the cradle could be even more valuable if it is a charger in its own right, and if it also double as a power bank or an external battery then it would be a truly incredibly valuable gadget. Nonetheless, this is an elegant and solid product that would be very useful to any iOS device owner.The cradle also has a penholder that is surrounded by the blue LED power indicator light. This is a neat addition and makes the cradle particularly suitable for work environments. However, the power indicator light is VERY bright, and thus it makes this cradle unsuitable for a bedroom or other places that require ambient darkness.

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-28: I was provided a VicTsing Data Sync Charging Cradle/Docking Station for testing and review and was asked only to give my honest review, so this is what I found.Look: The VicTsing Docking Station is lightweight plastic docking station with a small footprint. It is easily sturdy enough to hold up my iPhone 5 and looks to be sturdy enough to support the larger Apple iPads. It looks nice and has a nice build. It came in a pretty plain box with an USB Charging cable to plug into the back of it and no instructions (not that it really needed any).Use: I plugged in my iPhone 5 into the docking station without a problem. I was able to dock my phone without having to take off my Incipio Dual PRO case which was very convenient. The phone had plenty of room to spare around it in the cradle (probably because it also can be used for larger iPads), so I was initially worried that it moved around too much. I then realized that the Lightning Plug is mounted on a piece of plastic that is designed to move back and forth with a slight rocking motion. This allowed for a little movement without worrying about breaking off the Lightning Plug or damaging your phone like you could with a docking station with a fixed plug. This was a really nice feature.Performance: The big question when it comes to Apple Lightning Connectors on 3rd Party equipment is "Does it Work?" In my initial testing, I can say that it definitely does. I tested it using the standard Apple USB Wall Charging Block as well as a regular USB plug in my PC, and it both instances it charged perfectly. When plugged into my PC, it also had no problem syncing with iTunes. The charging speed was perfectly fine (about 1% per minute in my testing, which is normal) and the sync speed was the same as always. I saw no slowdowns at all and everything worked as you would expect.Conclusion: Overall, this is a nice Apple Lightning Docking Station. It passed the "Does it work?" test with flying colors despite my initial skepticism. If you are looking for a docking station for your new Lightning generation Apple product, this looks to be a great choice.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-13: good product for my phone after I figured out how to use it the customer service was okay but needs work

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-19: After failing to get an iPad WiFi 1st Generation open with a watch case knife (much too thick) and a 1.0mm thick nylon guitar pick (good for holding the screen up once popped loose, but not enough leverage to break it free from the clips initially), I came looking for tools and found this one with mostly positive reviews.I'll admit, when I opened the box upon its arrival, I was a little underwhelmed. True to their word, the tip does have any even thinner taper to it that makes wedging it between an iPad's back casing and the glass a fairly easy, but it felt thin and flimsy and I figured I could have just used a piece of stamped sheet metal from a local metal shop we have. However, after working with the iPad for several minutes, I found that there was one very big difference between this and just a plain piece of stamped metal, and that's the little padded grip. It seems like nothing when you first hold it, but that extra grip piece makes all the difference in being able to hold this tool fairly comfortably while applying leverage and pressure as you work. My hand still cramped after a bit (it was my first time opening an iPad, so it took me longer than the average YouTube instructional video), but it would have been horrible without that extra padding.The tool did bend a little more at the tip than I would have liked, but this tool is better suited for creating a gap so that you can then use some sort of plastic or nylon tool to apply additional leverage rather than using the iSesamo for all of your prying chores. Knowing what I know now, I look forward to using it more in the future, and I am very pleased with it overall. Definitely invaluable for working on an iPad while minimizing damage risk to the back casing or the plasic inner bezel/dust gasket.

    Rating: 4

    2013-01-21: This is definitely a tool you need if you have a habit of working on iPods, iPads, etc. it is on the thin side, so there's a little give to it but, better a little give, than to break things with it.

    Rating: 5

    2013-06-26: The tool fits comfortably in my hand the handle is non slip. I have used this tool several times for just the right tool to slip in a thin seem to pry/pop open. The tool is flexible yet plenty strong enough.

    2012-12-21: I am an IT & also do some electronic work. There are times when customers will bring me small electronic devices & ask me to look at them. This thin little tool has been a big help to open small electronic devices. I used it on small music players to get them open to look at & change batteries if thats the problem. It will open an ipod & you could change the batteries yourself, & save your money. There are many other music players out there & you can change the batteries yourself very easily. Personally, I do not own any Apple products because there a lot better products out there. One thing you need to keep in mind, if Apple makes it, Apple has to fix it. Thats the way the design their products. Highly recommend this flex tool. You will be very glad you ordered it.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-01: I perform repairs on a variety of electronics. This tool is perfect to pry at the edge of an iPad or Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 10.1 for screen replacements. I highly recommend this tool!

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-27: This is a wonderful tool to get you in trouble! It lets you open things that should forever be left closed. I opened my Kindle Fire for a charging port issue in 2 minutes no problem. The only issue I had with this tool is that it is stamped steel. One side had a burr or sharp edge that could scratch the item you are opening or cut you. I took one of my wife Carla's fine nail files and took the burr off. It really took me 2 minutes to do this. The covering on the tool is really fantastic non slip stuff and you can use both sides of the tool. It's thin and very flexible and springs right back from a bend. It's not meant to pull out nails but it's perfect for the intended use.

Good news is it still charges.What do I use them for? I run long distances and am on the road from 2 to 7 hours at a time.     $B0055QRUUC

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2012-01-20: This is a nice well built case. I bought this purely for a low profile (inherently has minimum protection) and cosmetics. I like the black brushed aluminum on the back. The biggest drawback for this case, is the plastic sides of the case, which makes it slippery to hold at times. The back can normally be made of any materials, as most of the gripping are on the sides. This falls short. It'll get really slippery if your fingers get sweaty. The gloss finish on the sides seem to show sweat more as well. If you want a nice looking case to use for a formal occasion, this is a nice choice. If you're looking for an everyday-use case, you will probably want to look for something more practical.

    Rating: 4

    2013-08-06: I got a lot of compliments while I used this case because of the brushed aluminum look and minimalist design. The case was great for a while but the thin portions along the top broke off after a few months so you should know about that if you are planning on getting this case but that should be expected from normal wear and tear. Did offer good protection also as it wasnt flimsy or cheap feeling.

    Rating: 4

    2012-03-06: This case was pretty much as advertised, came quicker than promised and is good looking on my white iPhone 4S. The only issue I have with it is that it does not extend beyond the front of the phone at all and therefore provides no protection to the front. Also, the sides are quite slick which doesn't help to prevent dropping it.Update: After two week of use, it has already cracked at a weak point along the top. I will be replacing it as soon as I can get a different case.

    Rating: 1

    2012-08-13: First of all, if you are looking for an extremely durable, protective case, this should probably not be your first choice. It is NOT an otterbox or something like that.Now, having said that, it is very solid. I had a CaseMate barely there black case before this, so I had an idea of what I was getting. This case is actually even more solid than my original barely there. It fits perfectly snug on my phone and all the cutouts match perfectly with the buttons. I have this on an iphone 4 from Verizon.I couldn't be happier with the look. It looks great. The case does wrap around each corner of the phone, so it will protect the corners from getting dinged. As others have mentioned however, the case sits almost flush with the screen, so there is NO protection for the screen if placed screen side down. I have a Zagg on mine, so I don't worry about it, but it might be a concern for some.Update:Well after only about a couple weeks, I started noticing that my phone was acting strange. It started to drop calls, lose signal, battery would drain quicker than normal, and reception in general was terrible. I could hardly talk to people because my calls were so choppy.At first, I didn't notice the problems started when I put this case on. Sadly it did take me two weeks to realize the coincidence of when the problems started. As soon as I realized this, I took the case off, and my phone has been back to normal. Really strange and not sure if others have experienced this. I can't imagine that a thin little piece of aluminum would cause that, but sure enough when I removed the case, my problems went away. Also, I did notice that my phone would get hotter with the case on. That was weird because my phone had never felt warm to the touch, but it did with the case on.Maybe I'm crazy, but this case really messed up my reception and battery life.

    Rating: 2

    2014-07-08: Beautiful, great price, gives off a great idea of quality and style. Love it.

    Rating: 5

    2012-07-16: First off, several reviewers seem confused about what the "Case-Mate Barely There Brushed Aluminum" case is supposed to be. If you go to the Case-Mate website, you can easily compare all their cases, and see their description of this product. The case is made of plastic, and has a brushed aluminum insert on the back. It provides minimal protection, but looks great. I saw a friend's gun-metal brushed aluminum case, so I decided to buy the black brushed aluminum. It looks like part of the phone when installed. All the ports are easily accessed, and the case fits perfectly. The case does extend slightly above the edge of the front, so your screen will not touch the table if set down on it's face. If you want something that looks great, while providing minimal protection, this is the case for you. If you are more concerned about protection, you should look at different cases like the Case-Mate Tough Case, the Acase Superleggera PRO, or the Otterbox Defender. I have tried all four cases, and all are good choices depending on your needs.

    Rating: 4

    2013-10-01: I really liked this case because of how unbelievably slim it was. It was like the case wasn't even there, which is why it's 4 stars. I am truly scared that even with the case that the phone will be damaged if dropped because of how slim the case is.There really isn't any extra protection, where as most other cases have rubber points or something to reflect damage. This case simply absorbs it and because the case is so tight and small, all of that energy absorbed is still sent right through the phone.Overall this case is beautiful and if you trust it to protect the phone, it probably will. I was a bit skeptical and was scared to fully test it out but hopefully this helps your decision.Thanks!

    Rating: 4

I can walk around my apartment without losing signal. No wires.Build Quality: The speakers themselves seems good, but the band seems like it may be a bit flimsy.Audio Quality (music): Good. Face it, at this price point, you will not get anything amazing, but these get the job done with pretty good audio.Audio Quality (Calls): Decent. I hear people good and they hear me clearly too.Conclusion: This headset is does exactly what it it says it does and for pretty cheap. If you need a stereo headset while you are doing things around the house, or working out, these are great. I would not recommend driving with these on, they're not the best at blocking out sound, but still very good at it and it may be dangerous to drive with them on.If you would like something with better audio/quality in general, I would highly recommend the LG Electronics Tone+ HBS-730 Bluetooth Headset. The audio (call and music) and build quality on that set is great. They are though, almost twice as expensive as this Kinivo set.

    Rating: 4

    2013-09-05: It works fine inside my house. It's comfortable to wear. But when I take it outdoors to listen to music on dog walks, the audio cuts out for two seconds once or twice per song.The other thing I didn't like was that it had a mini-USB connector, not a micro-USB connector, for charging. That indicates that might be an older product.I sent it back and got a Kinivo BTH240, which doesn't have any problems.

    Rating: 3

    2014-05-08: I like this product, however I gave only 3 stars to this review because I think that the plastic structure surrounding the headphones is not very good being in contact for a long time with the bones behind your ears. The quality of sound is pretty good, sharp sound etc, so it is up to you if you are looking for something cheap this is very good, it is also good if you don't like the oppressive feeling on your ears from a professional headphones.

    Rating: 3

    2013-09-30: For the price - it doesn't get better than this. The head set wraps around the base of your neck and wraps around your ears. The sets are well padded and don't add a lot of pressure on the ears. And the sound is great. I ordered this pair after another Bluetooth headset I had purchase failed after a weeks worth of use. So far no issues.I've used mine now for a week at my desk. Great for drowning out background noise and distractions while listening to music or podcasts. Highly recommend!

    2013-12-18: These headphones are great! They work awesome with my phone. Only problem is I didn't buy them to use with my phone... I bought them for my laptop. With my laptop the sound is great too, however i have to be sitting in front of it. Any sudden movement or especially if I go as far as standing up it starts to skip. That means I can't lay in my bed and listen to music or watch a movie without bringing my laptop over. Well I can but I have to be real still and not interrupt the signal. Other than that pretty good.

    Rating: 5

    2014-07-08: TheARCTIC P253BT Bluetooth Stereo Headphonesoffer amazing sound quality in a compact, over the ear headphone pair. The sound is truly impressive, and is much better than some of my headphones that have cost $100's +. I have found they can actually amplify the sound higher than that of my original device which make them excellent for devices that never seem to put out the right volume, even at max volume. Really good base reproduction too. Truly fantastic.Pairing is simple and straightforward, had no issues in that department. These are great to take on my afternoon jogs to enjoy music while I take in the scenery. These work great with my phone for hands free calling in the house and office and even have support for VOIP applications. I have paired them with my computer and use them for both skype and other chatting services. I sound clear, my caller sounds clear, just the way it should be.The ear pieces have a good amount of padding, enough to keep them comfortable but not too much to make them bulky. Just the right balance.Overall, I have found the Arctic P253BT Headphones to be solid performers and to deliver great results.[Review Sample Provided For Review And Evaluation]

    2014-05-27: I was about to give this a rave review. For the price, this product performs remarkably well.     Rating: 4

    2014-03-26: I was looking for an affordable yet quality bluetooth headphone and I found it in these Arctic P253BT headphones. They sound pretty darn good, cost is really affordable. I have used them to make calls and have a conversation with on the phone also. Volume controls on the headset are a little rough to use as you go in blind with them on trying to adjust sound. Increasing the volume on the phone or iPod has little to no effect to the sound in the headphones. The multi function button on the right ear is easy to get to, but a little touchy when using for multi function. I've accidentally called someone back when trying to turn them off, or played a song when wanting to make a call because of the press and hold or press multiple times actions to launch a feature. Other then that, you can't go wrong for the price and quality. They don't feel cheap, but of course they don't feel high dollar either, it's the perfect balance and a little above what you would expect for the price. The head strap is not adjustable, so be careful here, it fits pretty good on the lower neck or back of head but it's kind of small. Big necks beware! The earphones are comfy with plenty of padding and they fit pretty nice on the ears and don't fall off or anything. Haven't tried jogging or anything like that, but I would see issues doing much bouncing with these on.Overall a good buy for the price point and sound quality.

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-09: For the price, the sound quality is quite phenomenal on these. I find using the equalizer does help, but even out of the package, for the price, the sound is pretty good. No audiophile will accept the sound quality from these no matter what, but that's more to do with BT headphone capabilities than it is a reflection of the performance of these headphones.Bass is nice and deep, not too deep, and mids and highs seem to be fairly accurate.Pairing is very easy (hold down the power button until it flashes blue then red repeatedly, enable pairing on your device of choice and connect).The comfort level of these, thanks to them sitting around the back of your head, is very good. I wear glasses and have worn these for a few hours at a time just to try them out w/ glasses. No pain!The battery seems to last around 7-10 hours regularly, with regular use. I use these at a moderate level and at this level the power time seems to sit around 10 hours total. If you pump the volume all the way up, you will likely get less play time.In terms of how loud these get, I find the cups do a good job blocking ambient noise and keeping the sound in your ears. They aren't active noise canceling, but in public transit situations, they are adequate.Highly recommended.I received a free pair from the manufacturer for review purposes. I would pay my own money for these, as at this price the performance and sound quality are better than similar WIRED headphones I've used.

    Rating: 5

    2013-09-12: As an audiophile I can tell that the sound quality of these headphones are comparable to much more expensive models. After downloading the proper software for my BT USB Adapter, I have nothing but listening pleasure. Connects to iphone like wet to water, connects to tablet the same. If you don't want to spend a lot for quality sound this headset should do the trick for you. As far as comfort, the smaller your head the better, still they work for me just fine...

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-23: I have had 3 different versions of this headset over the years and they all are great until they fail. I wear these when I work out, and so they get very sweaty over time and are subjected to quite a bit of abuse. Even so, the headsets last about a year or two and sound great the entire time. The failure is usually the connector where the headset charges. Once it gets a little sweat on it, it seems to self destruct. This is one time that a cheep plastic part will outperform the expensive metal ones!I generally connect my iPod and phone both at the same time and listen to music on treadmill. When a call comes in, I can hear it because the music automatically cuts out and I hear the ringing.I keep buying these because they are comfortable and they sound good. The Bluetooth works well. I have purchased lower cost headsets and the Bluetooth does not connect well or looses the connection from time to time. Not good. These do not have that problem at all.

    Rating: 4

Looks-black on my white phone looks awesome. Some reviewers have said that it is 'baggy' on the side. Yes, it is; but not enough so it comes off or anything! Just a bit of give on one side of mine. Has just enough of a 'lip' on the front of the phone to set it down face first! The grid of squares on the back is nice looking. So overall; this get 4 stars. If you want a case that doesn't take a hammer to get it off; looks nice, and you don't drop your phone; this one is it!

I read that it should be surprising since the phone requires more juice than just 1470 mahs. Anyways, I've charged my iPhone 4 from 12% percent. After a while, hour or so, it only charged my phone between 57% to 77%. I think, when I turned my phone off, I manage to get it to 87%.I got the white case and had to get a black marker to blacken the camera area cause the photos with flash had a white blur in them. It worked.It gets really hot when I'm charging the case and phone at the same time. Especially when I'm using the phone during the recharging. I would suggest you charge the case first and then the phone. Obviously, you should know that heat breaks down the battery's capabilities in holding the charge. So please don't just charge it and ignore it. You didn't pay enough to garner that kind of technology that automatically turn off itself.I don't like that screen of the phone is a bit out of the case. Do NOT lay your phone facing down then. There is no space between the screen and the case like others.As long as it keeps chugging, I'm happy with my purchase with all of it's blemishes.

    Rating: 5

    2013-04-11: My job recently "upgraded" our work cell phones and got us some iPhone 4's - needing a case I went to the VZ Wireless store and was shocked to find that cases were $25-50 even for the older model Iphone 4. A coworker of mine bought this exact case from the store and paid $43 dollars for it. I found it here on Amazon and thought that it was going to be a cheap knock off - I was surprised to find that it is the exact same case, but it comes directly from China and not in the box or retail packaging. The case is great, it has a solid build and a rubberized texture to it. The case snaps on securely to the phone, and the phone in the case fits snugly into the holster. The clip on the holster is solid and rotates to your linking. The case and the holster also have a "kickstand" each for placing your phone in a position to watch videos / movies. The finish feels durable, and the case still allows for easy access to the buttons / controls. The only thing that someone who drops phones a lot would not like is that there is no protection along the top and bottom edges, the case grips the phone on each side. If the phone falls and lands along the top or bottom edges, there could be damage. I think that this case rocks though, and at more than $35 cheaper than in the store it can't be beat.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-21: This case works great. Kick stand is a bonus. Sells for a lot more in the stores. Have dropped the phone when getting out of the truck with no damage at all!

    Rating: 5

    2011-12-17: I am very picky on the right case for my new iphone4 and i tried pretty much all the heavy armor cases out there such as the otterbox/survivor/ballistic etc. when looked at online they looked great and the level of protection they reported to serve automatically sold me. HOWEVER..... when i recieved them they were terrible cases with very poor design. the otter box fell short in the fact that the shell does not snap together tightly and causes the iphone4 to shift inside. also the rubber silicone exterior would beome loose and contantly fall off its clips. the only thing good about the otter box was the holster. this also goes for the ballistic case with terrible holster. the survivor is a good case and loved it at first i liked it because the shell snapped around the iphone tightly and the otter silicone would not sag or come off unless you physically pulled it off. HOWEVER..... the big issues with this case are 1. the camera flap is too tightly secure 2. the silent mute button is damn near impossible to get to especially if you have bigger fingers 3. THE BELT CLIP SUCKS!!! downright SUCKS!!! 4. HEAVY and BULKY! it is not at all practical to carry in your pocket due to the chance of your pants falling down.NOW FOR THIS CASE REVIEW: all i have to say is WOW! awesome indeed it is. love the fact that it has all the features that i was looking for but in a very compact size. first off you have the holster. i always wear my iphone4 on my belt and very rarely put in in my pants pocket. slides in and out without any trouble but secure enough so it don't fall out when not intended to use. secondly the shell that incases the iphone4 is amazingly secure and fits like a glove. love how it feels in my hands and is very grippy. i dont feel like its going to fall out of my hands when in use. i also use a screen protector made by powersupport and its an antiglare film to minimize anoying glare when out and about. the case snaps on and donesn't interfere with the screen protector at all even when using the holster.so go buy a powersupport screen protector at your local Apple store or from powersupport.com. lastly the kickstand is the best feature. this baby is easy to slide and clips into place very snuggly and then retracts when finished. love the fact that it has the same design and pattern as the rest of the case for a stealth appearence.CONS: only con for me is that i wish i found out about this case a long time ago. i accidently bumped into this case at my local sprint store because i didn't care for the previous case i bought(spent $30.00) and could only exchange the item for another case. put this baby on and loved it ever since. i dont know who makes this case (not a name brand) but the manufacturer definatley hit the design and durability of this case on the nose. also i read alot of owner complain about it not having top and bottom protection. i dont find this a huge problem. yes it does have minimal protection on the top and bottom but if your careful and not clumsy with the iphone and place it back in its holster where it was inteneded to be placed when not in use its not going to be a big deal. i bought the iphone in white and love its design and this case helps preserve it beauty as it was inteneded to be. thank you

    2013-04-15: This kick stand case is much better than the last one I ordered, and the kick stand lasted much longer than the last one too, however did eventually break off (after about 3-4 months heavy/daily use)... This one had the cut outs for the head phone jack and charger which the other one didn't, and the kickstand didn't sag like the other cheaper brand I had ordered. the holster is just as flimsy, however I didn't buy this case AGAIN for the holster. other than that great grip and decently protective. WOULD recommend!
