    2013-02-22: I needed a case for my iPhone and didn't want to pay the store (cellular) prices. I was weary about this but so far it has lived up to expectations.

    Rating: 4

    2012-09-23: Very ingenious design with really two cases in one. I was looking for a belt clip holder for those times when it isn't possible to put my phone in my pocket or I needed quick access to my phone. I'm not sure how durable this will be since I've only owned this for a couple of weeks but the design that allows the case to turn into a stand is great. I will say that when the pnone is holstered it is more difficult to get out of the belt clip than I would like, which is why I didn't give it 5 stars. That could be a positive for some since I know it won't fall out accidentally. Overall I am pleased and for the times I want a belt clip or want to stand the phone up to view something this is a nice product...especially for less than 10 dollars!!! Don't ever buy one of these things in a retail store!!

    Rating: 4

    2011-09-22: Note: I do not use the holster part, so there will be no comments about it.The grip is quite nice. It's slick enough to slide easily into a pocket, but it's not slippery.The top and bottom of the iPhone is fully exposed, allowing any non-cradle charger to be used. Many cases do not have a large enough opening on the bottom to allow use of third party chargers.The side is open for the volume and mute controls, and the camera/flash opening is ample.The kick stand is simple and functional design. Well done!The one issue I have is with the front edges. If you do not use a screen protector, there is no issue. Most people I know use one, and the issue is that the front edges of the case essentially meet the edges of the screen protector. The result is that it is very hard NOT to loosen or damage the screen protector when installing this case.

    Rating: 4

    2012-11-30: Other reviews state it breaks easy. Not the case. My kids use it and it hasn't broke. And it's made to snap in holster backwards to protect your screen. Which another statement was made that it doesn't fit in holster right. Great price, great case and holster

    Rating: 5

    2011-07-16: I purchased countless things on Amazon and I believe this is the first thing I ever felt I just had to review (If I reviewed anything else I don't remember doing so). After shipping this came to less tan $ 9.00. It was in my hands 2 days after placing the order. This is the exact same case that the Verizon store sells for $30 plus tax. I would buy it for $30 if I didn't find it here for $8 and change. I don't like cases on my phones - whether it is a Blackberry or Iphone, if it is a nice phone I prefer to go commando...but if you are going to get a case for your Iphone get this one. First of all I won't tell you that you will get total protection because but the fact is it really only protects the back and sides and if you want a case the protects everything then your phone is going to be so wrapped up in a case it will look and feel nothing like the phone you paid good money for because you like everything about it including the feel. I think the way it is designed if you drop it the weighting will make it likely fall on the back or side anyway. This puts a little weight and bulk on your Iphone but not much at all - you still know you have an Iphone. A feature which I LOVE is the kickstand which comes right out then slides back in. I leave it standing on my desk in work all day and if I need to look at for any reason (email, website, photo, video, etc) it is standing right up - no need to pick up the phone. Same with just sitting on the porch listening to music - kickstand up, speakerphone on, music playing, cold beer in my hands, and my dog (or wife) in the other rocking chair - the kickstand alone is a selling point for me on the case and it lets you rest your phone either vertically or horizontally. Also the protection in the sides leaves one huge opening for the volume and mute buttons so they are simple to get to (as the unprotected top makes it simple to get to the headphone jack and on/off button). Perfect size opening in the back for the camera. The hard plastic has a great feel (not like those rubbery cases)and the pattern on the plastic is nice - its not just a plain black plastic case. Finally there is the belt clip - I don't really use it much because the bottom line is larger phones like the Iphone are big for a belt clip - but this was does rotate so you can turn it sideways if you want to - my friend has the same case and he tells me he uses the belt clip at work all the time (it slides in and out real easy when you face the phone to in the inside of the clip as directed but the phone is facing inside the clip so you only see the back of the phone from the outside....not sure why?) .If ever there was NOT a "You get what you paid for" item this is it - granted you don't get the fancy Verizon packaging and it just comes in a plastic sealed bag, but the second you take it out of the bag it is the $30 case from Verizon which is worth even what Verizon charges.

    Rating: 5

    2012-09-10: my friend have one look just exactly same from the picture but much expensive (he got $25+tax), when i saw this from amazon right away i order 3 for myself and friends, well.. the quality is quite the same but you paid what you got.. and actually for this price and no shipping charge, i have to say it's pretty good deal tho...

    Rating: 4

    2013-08-12: This is a very handy design. Clips to belt and is very accessible. It does take some effort so far to remove from holster. The kickstand is awesome. I open it when I am texting, slide my ring finger through the stand, and have much more stability when typing. And you cannot drop the phone when using it this way.

    2012-06-09: I use this product everyday. It is excellent and very attractive. Very cool looking and it is the source of questions everywhere I go. People can't believe I paid so little for an item this mice.

    Rating: 5

    2011-10-25: Update: 10/7/12There is another con that I'd like to address and because of it, I'm taking out a star.The phone is exposed on the top and the bottom because the case only covers the back and sides. I had dropped by phone on the asphalt and it unfortunately dropped and made a prominent nick on the bottom corner of the phone. So, the protection can be improved, but for the price, it's still a good case.--------------------- Original review below ------------------------I ordered several cases for iPhone 4S for our 4 iPhones. Out of all of these, I like this one the best. It was actually the least expensive of them all.Pros:1. Wonderfully tight, but not "damage your iphone"-tight, fit.2. The external surfaces of the case is slightly rubbery plastic that feels just right. Nice grip, if not a bit slippery.3. you can fit your iPhone 4, or 4S in many different orientations. I can have it facing up or down, glass side up or glass side down.4. The encased iPhone slides out of the holster easily, but it is securely held by the holster at the same time.5. Camera hole is nice and wide. It will not cause flash-reflection artifacts when the picture is taken with flash.6. The mic/speaker holes are well exposed. Some cases muffles the rings because the speaker is covered, but this doesn't have that problem.7. Craftsmanship is surprisingly good for a product that's $8 shipped. Amazing.Cons:1. The charging port is covered. But actually, you can reverse the way encased iPhone goes into the holster and then you can charge it without taking the phone out of the holster. So, there's actually no cons here.BTW, if it matters at all, I bought it from Niceeshop. They actually ship it from the oversea via USPS first class mail. It took about two weeks to arrive.

    Rating: 4

    2013-03-01: I spend most of my day near Wifi, but for the portions of my day while I am away from the network this device makes basic internet access easy. I enjoy the flexibility of having one mobile device to provide internet to any of my other devices. Where I live the t-mobile HSPA+ network does give 4G equivalent speed as promised. Battery life gives me 6 to 8 hours of mixed use. Also since the device runs on its own juice it doesn't further tax the battery power of any of my devices.Like all mobile broadband devices, this isn't a good choice for very heavy data usage like Netflix or large file downloading, but is more than adequate for most everything else.Make sure to check T-Mobile's coverage in your area, but overall great choice and flexibility and fairly reasonable rates 35 dollars for 3.5GBs w/o a contract.

    2011-12-03: I am savvy enough to root my own Android phone, so I am probably more competent than 75% of the customers who will buy this device, but I have failed completely so far, as I took two hours to figure out how to read a required text message that doesn't display on the device (eventually I found that accessing it on my iPad wasn't possible, but that I could read it on an Android device). I've spent more than an hour on the phone trying to deal with the horrid customer service on different issues, and am now stymied because I can see the field where I should enter the required temporary password that came in the above text message, but I am somehow unable to type anything in that field, despite trying on an iPad and two different Android devices from different manufacturers. The customer service phone number given in the manual does NOT connect you to the right people, and after slogging through an automated voice recognition system, you are connected to an operator who will connect you to the 4G phone service people, who will then tell you that they do not do hotspots, and send you to another person, who will then transfer you to yet another person, and eventually I find myself on hold long enough that I hang up and start over. Before each transfer, the CSRs (who very obviously do not have English as their first language) read a lengthy script telling you that they are not the ones to solve your problem and another department does it, but they will transfer you to another department who will immediately solve my problem because my problem is so important to them, and T-Mobile is committed....blah, blah. Before I abandoned my attempt (after over an hour, most of which was either on hold or listening to CSRs read soothing scripts that had nothing to do with solving my problem, I was interrupting the last CSR as he began his "I'm going to transfer you...." and asking, "Just transfer me!" and he would begin reading the script again from the beginning each time. He did not understand what I was asking, and I'm sure he thought I was being a total jerk. After I spent a lengthy period of time on hold, I hung up. I'm going to cool off for 24 hours, and give one more Boy Scout try at solving my problem. If I don't succeed quickly, this will go back to Amazon. From what I've read, it sounds like it will be a nice device if I can just break through the activation process and the ineffective system of customer service. (Check my other reviews and you will see that I am rarely if ever this critical).I'm sure I've had a worse customer service experience sometime in my life, but I can't remember it.

    Rating: 1

    2013-05-25: This T-Mobile hotspot is a lifesaver for those trips where hotels charge an arm and a leg for wifi. A $35 prepaid, no contract subscription gives 3.5G which is more than enough for casual surfing and some streaming. A great tool!

    Rating: 5

    2013-09-10: I decided to go with another Service Provider and T-Mobile won out. I have used Virgin Mobile and they keep changing their pricing on the Prepay and had a lot of no service because of Virgin Mobile says their up grading their net work. They never gave me any type of credit or extra time. So far I am very happy with T-Mobile and I receive faster service and more reliable connection for the same price. I love being able to use it as a flash drive. I didn't have any trouble activating it or connecting it to my Lap Top. I did have to buy a new sim card. I did have it activated at a local T-Mobile Store (Brick and Mortar).

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-03: I bought this because my internet keeps going out in the middle of the night, whether I'm on the phone (I have an internet home phone), watching a YouTube video, or even playing an online game. I waited for the right time on this device, my local Wal-Mart brought the price down by $15.My choices were T-Mobile, Verizon Wireless, Virgin Mobile, or some unknown MVNO that (like Virgin Mobile) uses Sprint towers. Verizon is the most expensive ($100 device, $60 for 3 gb's, but had best coverage). Virgin Mobile was close at $90 for the device, with about $30 to $40 a month, but uses WiMax for 4G. The unknown MVNO cost $75 for the device I believe, and it only receives 3G. T-Mobile's hotspot cost me $70 with the sale.PlansT-Mobile just released a new plan called Pay In Advance. It is the same plan as what you could get under their monthly service, except it's now prepaid (you'll need to have a debit card on file, auto renew is a must). $20 gets 500mb's of up to 4g speeds, anything after that is throttled to 2G. You can go up to 12.5 gb's of 4G for $80. When I activated my hotspot, I paid for the $50 5gb plan, which lasts 2 months since Walmart devices were eligible.Speed/CoverageThis device doesn't have LTE. It uses HSPA+, which I can't complain about. I live in a rural city and At&t;, T-Mobile & Verizon are the only ones who offer 4g out here. I get anywhere between 4&8 Mbps down and about 1mbps up on T-Mobile's HSPA+For the most part, I get coverage just about everywhere I go. Some are as I go to don't even have 3G yet, but it's only a small hit when I go through those places since I go right back into coverage down the road.DeviceThe device is so small that it resembles a compact cell phone, which makes it great for storing in your pocket and forgetting about it. It does get a little warm, but like another reviewer mentioned, not scorching hot. I haven't used this device enough to determine battery life, but using it for about an hour or so inside of a building used 1 battery bar out of 4.InternetI am able to get most places without any wait times. Only one website I went to didn't work on this device, but worked on my home internet. The ping is usually around 80-ms ping, so I was curious to see if I could play games online. I played Halo 4 and it didn't lag on me at all. It did use approximately 90mb's for a 10 minute game though.Overall I'm happy with it and I may even change to an unlimited 2g plan with more than 500mb's of 4g.12/24/2013I've had this device for about 3 months. While I have no problem with this device itself, as it still works just fine, I now have a problem with T-Mobile. After learning about the new auto-renew plans for pre-paid, I signed for the 500mb a month plan. On 12/18, about 2 weeks into my plan, I receive an email from T-Mobile stating my auto-enroll had been cancelled. I contacted them via email, they confused my hotspot for a mobile phone at first, but then later realized it and told me they'd send it upwards to the proper team. Its been 6 days since that first email and I've heard nothing. As of the last 2 days in a row, I am unable to sign up for any plan, as nothing shows up under available monthly plans. I'd hate to pay for another mobile hotspot as these devices aren't cheap. I paid $70 for this device, AT&T; & Verizon's are $100 a piece. That means once my data is up, I have no more internet to go on. I hate relying on public WiFi since I've had terrible experiences with them not working at all, or not working well.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-25: I bought this item with the intentions of using my already paid for plan. It didn't work with my sim. It does come with its own sim; but those plans cost $20 more a month. That's why these devices are locked to "Hotspot" SIM card only.I got a USB dongle and a TL-MR3020 instead. Works much better.

    Rating: 3

    2012-03-30: I use this hot spot because I do not get an adequate 3g data signal for my iphone in my work building. It works great. It's speedy and I love the portability -- I also use it on the bus to work. I use it with my iPhone, iPad and Kindle.The reason I didn't give it five stars is it was a pain to set up, but a call to T-Mobile customer service helped a lot.I don't know why some people are saying you need a contract with this device -- I'm currently signed with a 30-day 1 gb pass. In my opinion, it's a great deal, although I do find myself burning through data quickly. I may sign up for a contract plan since I am so impressed with the device.

    Rating: 4

    2013-06-01: I live in the boonies without cable and although we have a DSL line, download speeds are frequently .05 - .1 MPS, ping 2000+, and upload almost nonexistent. Finally decided to try a hotspot since I can get 4G at the back of my house. I bought this here at amazon from Below Market Cellular. It was supposed to be new, but it wasn't (had to remove someone else's emails). Nevertheless, I kept it because it works. After reading reviews here, I took it into a t-mobile store to activate and ensure that it would work. Moved it around the house to find the best signal, and used a wifi extender to get signal to my office. All is working as it should. Ping is under 100 and download is usually 4.5MPS. Need the max of 12G/mo which runs $80 plus tax. Added it as another line to my tmobile account. To control data usage, I've deleted automatic program updates (i.e., windows) and changed to notifications. Then I can use the pokey DSL and let it chug away overnight. I usually end up with a little bit of data to spare at the end of the month so then I watch all the videos and youtube clips that friends have sent that month. I'm glad to have this (sure miss city life) and recommend it.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-09: I love these cases. I bought one for the Note 2 last year. The Note 2 belongs to my girlfriend now and she still uses the Cimo case.I ordered one for the Note 3. Here's what I like about it.1. The textured sides improve grip.2. The case just looks nice.3. It fits snugly.4. With the case on, the camera bump on the phone doesn't touch the desk, so it won't get scratched or scuffed.5. Can lay the phone face down without the screen touching the table.6. All the cutouts (infrared, 3.5mm headphone jack, speaker grill, charging port, S-Pen, microphone) are all properly done.7. Volume and Power buttons are covered but easy to press.What I didn't like.1. Got a little warped in shipping (it was cold out). It still fit snugly, but the sides are bowed out a little bit (I can squeeze the case on the sides and there's a little give there where the sides don't touch the inside of the case). It isn't enough to remove a star or even be negative, but something I wanted to mention.I would highly recommend this case to anyone getting any of the Galaxy phones they support. They're sturdy, reliable, and they work well. I couldn't ask for more in a case.

    Rating: 5

    2014-07-23: good

    Rating: 4

    2013-12-28: the grips on this case are so amazing. i can hold my phone with one hand with the confidence that it wont slip of of my hand. the back isnt slippery whatsoever and it adds almost no bulk or weight to the phone. love this case. my daily driver so far.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-12: It's just what you'd expect, TPU, grippy sides, cutouts line up. The "buttons" aren't raised enough to feel very well, but they're smooth surrounded by the textured "grippy" so all's not lost in that regard, but it's not as easy as other TPU cases I've purchased. My gripe is the fit. It's either too short on the back-side or too long on the front side so that some of the silver frame shows on the top & bottom (landscape from the front). I can see where the Note2 rounder design would be a better fit; the sides are fine just because they're longer. (pics included)Edit: After a couple of removals, it's stretching, which makes it gap a lot, definitely more than the pics show. I've used it for about a week total. It's not behaving at all like other TPU cases I own, which are fine.Second edit: after having chewed through a few more cases, it seems like all of them gap around this particularly rectangular phone. I use a bumper, now, that overlaps onto the screen some, I love that this one has the BEST grippy sides I've ever used on a case (might even work for exfoliating nasty feet in a pinch; it feels like my dad's old wood shop rasp.)

    2010-11-29: Not too much you can say about a phone charger that works... ...this one does, exactly as described.At this price, I've bought several; I keep one in each of several vehicles and have bought one as a gift.Will work fine on other phones besides Motorola; does a good job on my Droid Incredible. Seems to fully charge the battery, but with no problems with overheating the battery/phone, which is a problem with many "cheap" chargers. I feel comfortable leaving my phone on the charger while driving (or even while the car is parked) with no worries about ruining an expensive instrument.

    Rating: 5

    2010-10-15: Way nicer than expected, works perfect and a very good priceMay be the best car charger I've ever had.

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-30: After so many months and trying the common web-popular solution of using an iPhone 4 approved charger with a USB port and a lightning to USB cable -which only worked when the iPhone 5 was close to fully charged- I can finally enjoy a car charger truly designed for the iPhone 5. Boy I'm happy!This is in essence the same Griffin model made for the 30 pin connector but with a lightning end and more amps to better fit the iPhone 5 charging needs, same coiled cable, same plug. I had one of those to charge my iPhone 4 and loved it, gave me many years of service, so for me this was a natural upgrade. I particularly like coiled cables, it avoids having a very long cable wrapping around anything on the front of the car, while giving you the flexibility to move far from the plug. I tried it and I got to the back seats of the car with the connector still holding on the iPhone. The coil is still a bit strong but it's new, with time it will get easier I'm sure, as it did with the previous oneBuilt quality is good, cable is strong and the connector fits the iPhone as if it were Apple's original. The bulb is made of hard plastic -as expected and as almost all car chargers around- and it fits very nice and tight on my Prius aux plug. The cable is part of the unit, meaning there is no USB connector to separate the cable from the bulb. This is good for me as I don't have to deal with misplaced cables or disconnections while the coil is stretched, but for some people it might be an issue. It also helps to keep the bulb very small and with a very low profile when plugged into the carHaven't measured charging time or compared them with the specs, but it fully charged a 25% charged iPhone 5 in a less than an hour, which in my opinion it's very good for a car charger.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-30: Works very well to charge my phone, haven't had problems yet, will update if something happens other than regular use.

    Rating: 5

    2010-04-14: Had it a few months, no problems - lights up blue looks awesome. Great for verizon motorola droid

    Rating: 5

    2011-06-14: This thing lives in my targa-top Honda Del Sol. My car is a beater, so I seldom put the top in, even when it's supposed to rain.So, even though I wouldn't recommend this as a normal occurrence, this charge has been rained on, frozen (near 0 dF) and baked in direct sunlight, yet still charges my smartphone. And it's less than a third of the cost of what Verizon would charge you in a store.I bought two of them and my brother stole one to charge his Blackberry Storm (it's a run of the mill micro-usb connector).

    2013-04-09: There isn't much to say other than this product works great. The coiled cord is long and pliable enough that I can stretch it out and set the phone on my lap. The iPhone 5 "Lightning" connector fit perfectly into my iPhone, and charged immediately.This product is compatible with the following items:1) iPod touch 5th generation (32/64GB)2) iPod nano 7th generation (16GB)3) iPhone 5 (16/32/64GB)4) iPad mini (8/16/32GB)5) iPad 4th generation (16/32/64GB)The product even comes with a one-year warranty of sorts from Griffin Technology.A single downside from what I can see: The cigarette lighter insert is slightly L-Shaped, and I could see this being an issue with some cars. If the cigarette lighter is recessed very much, the connection may not work correctly.I'll buy this product again if I need another car charger.

This one does not.

    Rating: 3

    2010-08-27: I've had this for a few months, and just picked up another for my wife. While it says this is for the Droid A855, it works with any micro-USB device.Personally, I've used it with theNokia N900,BlackBerry 9700, Nexus One,Kindle 3G, and MyTouch 3G Slide. It's moved from car to car, person to person, and doesn't show any signs of the plastic weakening or the connector bending.The only real drawback this charger has is the glowing blue Motorola logo. If your 12V adapter isn't switched, it's going to glow blue the whole time it's plugged in, and could draw some unwanted attention to your car in a parking lot. The logo is also a bit wide, so if space around your outlet is at a premium, it might take some wiggling to get this to fit right.Really though, for what this costs, you're getting an outstanding quality product. Most of the knockoffs in this range use ultra thin plastic, and don't hold up well. This is definitely a step up, and would easily cost five times as much in an AT&T; / Sprint / T-Mobile / Verizon store.

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-30: I've had a lot of car chargers over the years - as I am sure many of us have in the digital age. They are always a varying level of quality or features. Some times even the OEM charges are not designed or built well. Fuses blow, cords permanently stretch, ends get gunked up with things from the car, etc...For the first time I can say that this is a truly great car charger. It simply does exactly what it is supposed to do, does it quickly and then also seems to be built like a tank. The coils have just the right amount of tension and the connector fits snugly. And then, there's the light. Unlike many chargers with a little LED, this features a white light ring that comes on when the charger is plugged in. It sheds just the right amount of light in the car to help you see things at night, without being distracting - although I am sure that depends on where your socket is located.If you are in the market for a car charger, this one rocks!

    Rating: 5

    $B003ZHV6D0

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2011-07-13: Boke within a week? The part by the volume control broke in my purse ... Why can't they make things worth the $$

    Rating: 1

    2010-11-01: Thanks to the previous post and a quality product description I ordered this case for my partner. So far it seems like a good case for anyone looking for a combination of silicon and clear crystal hard case. The silicon around the edge buffers the phone from bumps and the hard part buffers it from scratches. It arrived quickly with standard shipping and he was off and running with it.

    Rating: 5

    2011-01-28: I am not commenting on the durability of this case, since I just got it today, but it is a great match for my white EVO, as it lets the dazzle of the white back show through. Nice. The case LOOKS stellar.My only complaint is the main reason I bought the case. The phone is too slippery without a case - you simply HAVE to have a case for this phone or it WILL eventually slip from your hands. This case adds a little bit of tackiness to help keep it from slipping, but the back is too hard and smooth, and it will still slide around on a smooth surface. This is a problem if you need to set it on the dash as you drive, or place it on the arm of an easy chair for example. It really needs a more "rubberized" or tacky finish all around.I'll try this a little longer, but I may end up going with a more conventional silicone case, which will probably absorb falls a bit better, too.

    Rating: 4

    2010-12-02: This was the first case I bought for my Evo. Having TPU around the edges is better than silicone in my opinion because it TPU does not attract lint. Having a clear back was nice too, because it preserved the original looks of the phone.But...This case is difficult to put on and even harder to take off. In fact, the TPU surround tore away from the clear back as I was attempting to remove the case. Removing the case was a struggle because it fits tightly (fitting tightly is not a bad thing though). The TPU is clearly not adhered well enough.I was also not satisfied that the camera was protected. When in this case, the camera lens is flush with the clear back, meaning the lens would still be resting on the table if I set the phone down with the phone's back facing the table.

    Rating: 3

    2010-10-08: This case is perfect. It's exactly what I need. So I'm very frustrated that it just fell apart.I got it at the beginning of October. It's December 16th, and the black sides of the case just came free of the clear back. I'd understand this if I'd abused the phone and the case, but it spends most of the day sitting on a desk. To carry it with me I slip it into a cargo pocket. There's nothing else in that pocket, since I don't want to damage the screen. There are a few scuff marks on the back of the case, but very little wear. I never removed the phone from the case and it fit well right up to the moment when it fell apart.Everything I wrote in the previous review is true: the case is slim, it fits well, it doesn't change the look of the phone, buttons are easy to push through the case. It's really the perfect case for me. But I do need it to last more than 10 weeks.I'm moving on to aSeidio Innocase. Too bad.Old (October) review:I was a little nervous about buying this case since it had no reviews, but thought I'd give it a try. So far I'm glad I did.I haven't dropped the phone (yet,) so if (when) I do, I'll update the review then. These are initial impressions.The case didn't really change the look of my phone at all. It's got a slightly raised lip around the screen, so when I put the phone down face-down, the screen doesn't come into contact with the table at all. The sides seem thick enough to protect against normal abuse. The back is clear and beginning to accumulate scratches which can only be seen when I hold the phone at a sharp angle so the light reflects off the case. In normal conditions it looks undamaged. The case is smooth plastic and slides quickly and easily out of my pocket.Everything that requires access can be used through holes in the case, except for the power button. For that, the case has a thin, raised spot that I thought would be difficult to use, but it's very easy--almost no extra force is required.The case was very easy to put on, but is difficult to remove. Since I don't have a reason to remove it, I never do.I haven't had it for long, but so far it doesn't seem to be stretching or losing its shape at all.I'll update this review if there are problems later on, but for now, this case is perfect for me.

    Rating: 1

    $B0018L4GOQ

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2009-06-21: I have order 4 of these adapters, and they work great, I can finally use all those old Motorola power adapters that I have lying around. I have a Blackberry Storm that this works with.

    Rating: 5

    2011-07-15: I ordered this item as I already had 5 of the Motorola Mini-USB to Micro-USB that were working well from an earlier order with another company. When this one arrived I noticed that two of my phones (a Droid Global 2 and an LG) would not work with these (I ordered 5 of these). Both of the adapters are molded plastic with the ID SKN6252A. The ones that work look just a little better built and are 97 mm versus the ones that don't work which are 85 mm. Both have a hologram with the M trademark, but I suspect the ones that do not work are counterfeit. At least they were cheap.

    Rating: 1

    2009-09-20: If you have devices that use both the "mini" USB charger (older Motorola & Blackberry phones) and "micro" USB charger (newer Motorola and Blackberry) this is a great way to reduce the number of power bricks you have to carry around with you. I bought two of these - one to use for traveling, and the other in the little front drawer of our Pottery Barn "charging station" so I can charge both types of devices from the same tip when at home. The little lanyard is a mystery to me - not sure the purpose, but the build quality is very good and the price is certainly right compared to the cost of an additional charger.

    2013-03-21: *UPDATE 3/25/2013* I raised this to five stars because the issue I had was my fault. I didn't realize that if I pushed the mini-usb connection in harder, it would snap together and make a very solid connection.This adapter is small and has a feature I like and a small issue that is annoying. I have a gaming headset at home with a long USB cable for charging but I would like to charge my phone as well so this adapter is a good solution. I like that the cord keeps it attached to the main USB cord (it's not necessary, but a helpful feature). Unfortunately I'm having the occasional issue with it not charging and I believe it is because of the adapter not having a great connection. Moving the adapter fixes the issue and my phone starts charging. I think it earns a solid 4 stars.

    2010-04-14: I recently received several Nokia E63 phones for family members. The phones did not include the data cable, which is needed to apply firmware updates. So I ordered a couple of these Motorola SKN6252A miniUSB to microUSB adapter cables.Pros* Transmits power to the device; n/a for Nokia e63, ok for BlackBerry with microSDHC* Transmits data to the device* Allows using miniUSB cables from other devices such as a portable hard drive or some BlackBerry* Short cable (about three inches) relieves pressure from the connector on the device as compared to a non-cable adapter* It is an OEM (original equipment manufacturer) adapterCons* None so farI can confirm this adapter works perfectly on both Mac OS X using iSync and Nokia Multimedia Transfer, and on Windows XP using Nokia PC Suite.

    2009-11-02: Like I said in another review: All mini USB's do not work for every charger, for every cell phone.Case in point: I have my GPS with its car charger (USB). They must designed the power pins anyway they felt like, because a mini USB power charger is NOT universal. I hear that by Oct. 2010 (in Europe at least) all cell phone will have a universal mini USB charging port - you should be able to charge them thru your computer and you'll never will have to throw your old charger away, just because you got a new phone! Or you can charge your phone with your buddy's charger...no problem. A very sensible, bright idea I should say!But we are not there yet!THE GOOD PART: The exchange went very smoothly, and the people involved were helpful and understanding!!

    2013-05-31: Because I "hate" wires dangling from my windshield, I have my GPS hard-wired through my headliner. Over the past 12 years, every new Tom-Tom I bought used the Mini-USB, until now! There is no difference in the operation of my Tom-Tom GO Live whether I use the power cord supplied or use my old power lead with this adapter. This is a high quality product at a very "value friendly" price. Also, this adapter makes a very secure connection.     Rating: 5

    2013-05-07: I have purchased (usually from my cellular provider or retailer for about $1) and used several of these adapters with various devices over the past several years and EVERY single one of them has eventually "failed". The average life expectancy of these adapters, for me, has been about 6 to 9 months. After the initial "failure" I've found that I can wrap or coil the cord around the device to maintain the angle or pressure on the connection - which works about 80-90% of the time. I have no experience on how long this "fix" lasts, as the inconvenience annoys me into replacing the defective adapter after a short time.I have not tested the data throughput rates with these, so I have no comments on that... other than that they do allow you to transfer data via USB.Overall, these have been good adapters... when they work - especially for the $1 each price I paid. I just hesitate spending more than $1 each on these adapters given the short life I've experienced with them. In my experience these adapters should rate the same life-expectancy as the Mini-USB cables they are attached to (or any other data cable for that matter... rated in years, not months).

    $B00FF1EBLS

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2014-06-26: With the fierce competition of headphones out there, finding a sleek and effective pair is getting harder to find. This pair fills that gap between too expensive and cheaply made without sacrificing quality for iOS devices.The look of the headphones was clean and the magnetic and interchangeable colored panels (they call them tags) on the earpieces allow you to have some customization in the look. I like that the headphones came with two additional sets of colors. You can see how it looks in their images above. They panels were so simple to swap out.The foam padding around the ear pieces felt great. While these are not noise cancelling headphones, the memory foam did reduce some outside noise. Not having the noise reduction technology keeps the cost down as well. I wore them around the house for quite a long time. Most headphones begin to hurt after a while. I did not notice that with these. I also like how the earpieces folded down to allow you to hang them on your neck easier when not in use.The audio quality was not bad at all. These are not perfection for the audiophile nor or they meant to be. It did not have the heavy bass enhancements most headphones try now thinking that makes everything better. They played cleanly and sounded good. The in-line audio controls on the cord allowed you start/stop/forward/back of your audio.The in-line controller also has a noise reduction microphone for use as a phone headset. Hearing the other caller was clear and they did not have any complaints over my voice quality until the in-line controller rolled over. I love how they made the controller closer to the face instead of way down the cord. This means the microphone for the phone is actually near my mouth. They were missing a clip to hold it at the right angle though. You can also use the in-line controller to pick up and disconnect from calls.The packaging itself was a little overkill to be honest. They could reduce that down a bunch. It is like they tried to make it stand out on the gaming shelves (they have many headsets in that area) or against other headsets.Overall, a recommended product with good sound, good pricing, audio controls and double use as a phone headset for iOS devices.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-07: These are really great sounding, clear, comfortable headphones! I've tried many different types, all price ranges, and these are the best I've used yet. I will say that they are the most expensive I've tried but they are worth the price of under $80.00. They do cut out the room noise really well. My 17 year old daughter tried to claim them after hearing how awesome they are!! (you know how teenagers are!) Of course I told her, too bad, so sad!! These are mine!!

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-18: Most of the time, when walking around outside or doing my chores, I wear my JBL ear buds to listen to music from my iPhone 4S to help pass the time. However, when given the opportunity to try out the Kunai headset by Tritton (Do they really have their name in all caps?) I stopped using my JBLs and used the Kunai for a month straight and am relatively satisfied with the results.Despite the large nature of my head (being 6'5 and all), the Kunai fit relatively comfortable on my noggin with room to spar. This is uncommon as most headphones are designed for smaller people below 6 feet tall and look more like miniature Mickey Mouse ears on me than actual headphones and are just as (un)comfortable. Now, to put their comfort to the test, I immediately took them with me for a 2-mile brisk walk around the neighborhood in 75 degree weather. Not hot, by any stretch, but warm enough to get me to sweat a little and see how well the Kunai handle under those conditions. They did well as they stayed on my head without any serious shifting and/or sticking to my face as others had done in the past.After a few days of subjecting the Kunai to walking around hard outdoors, and performing relatively well I might add, I then wore them outside on the porch during my downtime after a shift for about a week to see how comfortable they were in a relaxing environment where comfort is more heavily scrutinized. The Kunai seemed relatively comfortable even while in direct sunlight and I was just sitting there observing every minute detail in the headphones.It was also during these trials that I noticed more about the sound quality. It's not going to bring the house down but they're good and, more importantly, balanced. My biggest criticism of competing headphones, most notably Beats, is that they place an overwhelming emphasis on base power and not clarity or balance making the ear pieces all about bass and nothing else; it just ruins high-quality soundtracks and songs. The Kunai are an excellent balance between bass and clarity allowing me to hear every detail in my songs, which are highly comprised of instrumental soundtracks from film and gaming. They won't bring the house down but I can tell that the Kunai are more tailored towards casual and economic listening rather than the higher end.As for ease of use with the iPhone, I performed several call tests outside and in my loud laundry room to see how well the person on the other end could hear me and they worked VERY well. It's handy to have headphones that don't need to be removed during calls allowing me to listen to music and take calls seamlessly. HOWEVER, despite the instructions tell me that the Kunai are compatible with my iPhone 4s in terms of using the song skip features, I can only seem to get the play/pause button to work. Perhaps I missed a step but that shouldn't be the case. Oh well.Oh, and you can change the color of the panels on the muffs to be either black, orange, or red… cool, I guess. I never changed them from their detailed black and threw out the replacement panels. I don't wear orange, anyway.All in all, the Kunai are a good quality set for the price. Won't bring down the house like JBL or Klipsch will, but they're good quality all the same. I'm still going back to my JBLs, though. :P

    Rating: 4

    2014-05-04: I have a lot of headphones and headsets. I have Bluetooth models, a couple high-end wired ones, some studio headphones for when I'm making music, and other little cheap-o earbuds and things for convenience. That said, I rarely use most of them. Some are just uncomfortable, some are inconvenient, and some don't please me with their audio quality. For the record, I absolutely HATE beats by Dre (and Monster, masters of overpriced accessories and hyperbole) and I'm none-too-fond of 50-Cent's bass-heavy headphones, either. My favorite `phones have been my trusty Koss PortaPlay (purchased 20 years ago, and still outperforming most in the price range and lasting longer) and my BlueAnt headset. My least favorites (aside from the aforementioned fashion accessories by Dre and 50-Cent) are most earbuds packed in with anything, and my first pair of lower-priced, over-ear Sony Studio Headphones, which had excellent sound quality but had a tendency to crush my ears and head, making extended use impossible.When I got the TRITTON Kunai headset I was expecting something in the middle-of-the-line range, and for the most part that's what I got. However, the build quality and sound are much better than I expected from accessory company Mad Catz, who have made some of my least-favorite controllers and game accessories over the years. Clearly, they brought their A-game to this headset. I was impressed.► Build: The TRITTON Kunai feels nice and solid. The whole unit has a nice rubberized feel. It's like these headphones were made with shark skin. They're sturdy, and the magnetic, replaceable, colored side panels allow some customization without a lot of effort.The cable is hard-wired into the headphones-- something I consider a negative-- and the in-line controls are, in my opinion, WAY too close to the main unit (and your head) making it impossible for you to look at the controls when you use them. I would have preferred the controls to be lower by about 6", because I'm not always certain I'm hitting the right button despite the raised symbols on them. My fingers just aren't that sensitive, and I'd like to look at the controls when I use them sometimes.The ear cups are very soft and feel great. Oddly, they're rectangular-shaped instead of circular or oval. They do a great job of sealing and providing maximum comfort while blocking out the outside world and keeping your music or phone conversation to yourself.The cord itself could be longer at 3.9 feet. It's not a major complaint, but with it being hardwired into the main unit, it means you have to consider an extension if you need more slack.► Sound Quality: These have a range of 20 Hz - 20 kHz. What that means is that don't get super-bassy, though they handle bass well, and they don't get up in the highs that I, as an adult, can no longer even hear. That's OK for me. For a teenager these might seem a little more limited in range because they can hear more high notes than I can.The mids are fine, not muddy or "thick", and everything is clear. As headphones go, these are a couple notches above average in terms of audio quality, but they're not any threat to Sennheiser, Klipsch or even some of BlueAnt's best stuff. I think they're better than the bass-heavy, muddy garbage by Dre or 50-Cent, but then I'm not a huge hip hop fan (at least, not hip hop after 1990) and like to hear details in my music, which the TRITTON Kunai handles admirably well. Again, not top-of-the-line by any means, but certainly not junk like many headphones on the market these days.As noted previously, these aren't super-bassy. If you're a bass fan, you may want to stick with the other guys. If you want clear bass that mixes with the rest of the music, then these might do the trick.For voice, they're good. They do add a richness to voice calls that isn't present in my Bluetooth headsets and earpieces, and they do a great job of filtering out noise.► Function: The TRITTON Kunai headset is pretty specific in the title about being for Apple iPod, iPhone, and iPad. This isn't a lie. I tried these on my Android phone and they worked fine as a headset, but the controls were completely useless. None of the in-line controls worked. I couldn't control volume, playback, pausing, or answering the phone with them. This could be because my phone didn't play nice, or it could be that they were serious about the whole "for Apple" thing.However, in the quick-start guide, they also list the PS Vita, Nintendo 3DS, the Wii U gamepad, and "Tablets/Phones" as being compatible. What "compatible" means is questionable. I guess your mileage may vary. The packaging says the in-line controls are only compatible with Apple devices, so I'm thinking the compatibility with those other devices may not include the in-line controls and is only referring to their function as a headset. You can get the microphone and headphones to work but you can't control the device with the headphones.On my iPad mini, the TRITTON Kunai performed well. Double-clicking the middle button skipped tracks. Single-clicking paused and played. the volume buttons worked as they should. I was pleased, and found myself wishing these controls worked on my Android phone.► Packaging/Info: The packaging is, frankly, a mess. I won't consider this in my review score, but it should be known that Mad Catz really made a messy package here. The outside sleeve has ALL information presented in five different languages, which makes it cluttered and hard to find what you're looking for.Inside, they provide a two-page quick-start guide and direct you to go online for a full manual. Considering the price of this headset, I'd think a physical manual wouldn't be too much to ask of them.They also provide some stickers with the TRITTON logo on them. I have no idea what I'd use these for, but perhaps they'll appeal to teenagers who like stuff on their locker or Trapper-Keeper. To me, they're silly fluff and I'd rather have seen them spend the printing efforts and material on a real manual.►► The Bottom Line: The TRITTON Kunai Stereo Headset by Mad Catz is a great wired companion to your iOS device. Good sound, excellent comfort and build quality, and some nice customizing touches make this headset a good choice. I have to dock a point for the short cord and in-line controls too close to the main unit, making it a little more awkward to use them. This lost point is also considering the odd choice to include stickers instead of documentation. Still, this is a well-built headset that will satisfy most buyers who want it for an Apple device.If you're looking at this headset for Android, Windows Phone, or any other device, you may want to knock another star off my review, because the headset won't do much of what you're looking for, and it's not designed for those devices. It will support them to some degree, but it's not going to do the job if you want in-line controls.Recommendation: If you're an Apple device owner, get it. If you're not an Apple device owner, shop around first.

    Rating: 4

    2014-06-19: I like over-the-ear headsets, but never for very long. It always seems to be the weight, or the springiness, or the ear-fit that makes me weary of them after a 30 minutes or so. This Tritton set, however, is light and comfortable - they aren't overly springy but still stay on my head pretty well. The fit is good and I can wear them for hours without getting uncomfortable.

    Rating: 5

    2014-04-27: Executive summary: This is the best headset I used in a long time. It is light, high fidelity and elegant.Details: The product came very well packed. Inside the box you find the headset, some stickers, a simple user guide with warranty details, and a couple of covers to replace the original black one with either an orange cover or a red one. This replaceable piece is over the ear and if you have more than one headset, it is nice to distinguish which one is yours.Although it is said that the headset is for iPhone, iPad, iPod, I initially tested it on my Windows7 Laptop and it worked well, although the controls for volume did not work (and they were not supposed to work). Then I tested on my iPhone and yes, everything worked as advertised! Finally I tested it on my sound equipment. Again the controls did not work, but the quality of reproduction of the sound is really amazing. Impressive how much of the exterior sound is filtered and how comfortable this headset is. I used for 2 consecutive hours and it did not bother me at all.If I could just suggest for the designers to place the control 20cm farther from the headset down the wire, this would be perfect, but this is just me and this minor issue is not enough to prevent me from grading this product with 5 starts.I recommend this product to any person who is serious about hearing quality sound.

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-20: I love this thing. According to the advertized specs I should be able to recharge my ipod touch or my phone three times before the battery is drained! No lights when you are charging other objects, but honestly they have charging indicators on their screens so it isn't really necessary.Only minor issue I had was that seller contacted me a few days after order and told me that the lot of black units they had on hand were defective and wanted to know if a pink one could be substituted. I said yes and covered the pink anodizing with a piece of tape. Now that I've used it for a bit I'm thinking a piece of shrink tubing is in order for a more permanent fix. Not a major issue obviously, but I don't tend to get hung up on such things.Bottom line, great product. I love it.

    $B005C9G2P6

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2011-09-22: The first day I wore these to work, two coworkers commented on how large they are.Pros:1- Good clean sound.2- Open ear design allows you to hear cars honking or bicyclists werbally warning you.3- Has a short cord for armband carry but also comes with an extension.4- Won't fall out when jogging.5- Can be used in the rain.6- Clip included which takes up the slack on the cord by clipping cord to your clothing.Cons:1- Very little bass.2- Uncomfortable after 1 hour.

    Rating: 3

    2011-10-12: It's good for wearing while working out because they sit well over the ears and are not slippery. It has buttons to control the music volume and skipping songs. You could also push the button to answer calls, like any other regular Apple head-sets. But the sound quality is really what kills it for me. The regular Apple head-set sounds so much better than this. I'd rather give up on the sporty design for the better sound quality. That'd be my choice. If the sound quality could have been better, it'd have been a much better product for me, considering that it also comes with extra ear buds and a small case.

    Rating: 2

    2011-10-23: I'm getting so used to in the ear earphones that I was surprised for a minute, that these sit just outside the ear. The effect it has is that you are listening to the radio, but can hear all the background noise perfectly clearly. I liked that for walking down busy New York streets and still being able to hear a car horn or your name being called out (I've had friends accuse me of 'blanking them' when I was wearing other noise cancelling headsets.) My only concern that they were a bit fiddly for me to put on and because I wear glasses with quite thick plastic arms, it felt a bit crowded behind my ears. I think if I wore ultrathin wire frames (or no glasses at all) it wouldn't be an issue, but the these ear pieces are thicker than normal and it wasn't immediately comfortable.Sound quality was good, and connection to the rest of the world was also good, comfort was average, I liked them.

    Rating: 4

    2011-09-19: I wear headphones a lot: At work, on public transit, at the gym, you name it. The popular, over-the-ear headphones are great if you don't want something particularly portable and don't mind having your hair restyled every time you take them off. If these things are a concern, then earbuds are the way to go. But the earbud-style headphones are a problem at the gym. They fall out. The cords are too long and get tangled in the equipment. On transit and at work, the open-air style of most earbuds doesn't block outside noise very well. Enter the Jabra SPORT.PROS1. BUILD QUALITY. The build quality of these headphones is immediately apparent. They use high-quality cording and the connection points are sturdy. My Apple headphones fall apart a lot because I'm hard on them. These Jabra earbuds will definitely sustain far more wear and tear than typical earbuds.2. SHORT CORD. At the gym, my headphone cord often gets wrapped around some element of one of the machines and yanks my earbuds out. The short cord prevents this from happening by eliminating slack.3. EXTENSION CORD. The cord extension supplied with the headphones attaches easily to the headset and gives you a more typical cord length.4. TACTILE REMOTE CONTROL. The on-cord remote control is more tactile than the one on the earbuds supplied by Apple. The three raised dots make it easy to manipulate your music or phone call while exercising.5. STAY IN PLACE. The wrap-around design keeps these headphones in place regardless of the vigor of your activity. They're pliable and can be manipulated for a custom fit.6. ACOUSTICS: For earbuds, I find the sound quite good. The comfort eargels actually improve the acoustics when correctly positioned and can improve the bass significantly. Be sure to try all three. Finding the right ones to fit your ears make a huge difference in sound and the headset's ability to block out outside noise.CONS1. COMFORT. My ears are physically fatigued after wearing these for a while. The get sore from the multiple contact points and from positioning them for the best sound. In addition, glasses wearers beware. The wrap-around position is not the best for you and the weight of your glasses will add further discomfort.2. INSTALLATION. Installing these on my ears is a bit of a pain. They're not like popping in a couple of earbuds or slapping on pair of over-the-ear headphones. They take some manipulation to get the sound, comfort, and stability right. You'll find yourself rethinking removing them for conversation.3. APPEARANCE. Why does yellow = sports? How about neutral black or white? Especially something wrapping around my ear. I want subtle. A coworker pronounced that they'd look fine at the gym, but she wouldn't wear them on the bus.Overall I think these headphones are solid and bolster more pluses than minuses, but I'd definitely consider the cons if you wear your headphones a lot, care about appearances, and frequently pull your headphones on and off of your head.****UPDATEI am less impressed with these headphones over time. The sound is sub-par and when working out for long periods of time, they chafe the area behind my ears...once so bad that there was bleeding. I still think they are built well, but maybe too well. Too much going on around the ear than is really necessary.

    Rating: 3

    2011-09-26: The regular Apple headsets would fall out of the ears when used for running. These ones are perfect - and I especially like the extension when I place my ipod on my belt. If you have a small mp3 player on your armband, you can use it without the extension. They are Military standard (according to the box) and look very cool. The headsets are comfortable for my ears, yet a little large for my wife's ears.

    Rating: 5

    2011-09-23: The one drawback is that this headset is on the large side. However, the sound comes in clean and crisp; you can still hear outside sounds such as sirens and bells if you wear them out. As an added bonus, you get an extension cord as well as a short cord to carry as an armband.If you like to jog, bike or just walk, you don't have to worry about these falling out. They are weather friendly and can withstand the rain. They can also withstand sweat. Clips assure you that they can be securely fastened to your clothing, such as when you ride your bike or use exercise equipment.

    Rating: 4

    2011-10-20: Overall, this is a good headset. I wanted to try these out because they looked more comfortable than other over-ear headsets - and they are! The sound is also quite good. And I feel like I get good volume out of them on my iPhone as well. Something about the cord in conjunction with the earpieces makes for terrible tangling in my bag, but that's more a reflection on me than the product.Pros:Clear soundBendy over-ear bits really are bend-to-fit! With a little practice, I could get them to stay on.Most comfortable over-ear headset I've triedHigh-quality microphoneModular/2-piece cord - so you can make the cord shorter or longer depending on where your audio device is (armband vs pocket for example)Clip on the cord - so simple, but so usefulCord seems well made and durable (haven't killed it yet!)Cons:Bass is a little weak but not horribleNot easy to put on quickly (such as when trying to answer the phone)Still not super-comfortable to wear for a long time (more than an hour)I think they're worth the price. I wouldn't have normally gotten this style but now that I've tried them, I like them!

    Rating: 4

    2011-09-22: These headphones are so comfortable and stay in place so well. I love that they allow me to turn on my music, start jogging, and forget about them completely. So many headphones hurt my ears and these don't at all and they don't fall out or slip at all. The only thing I don't like about them is that they only work with Apple products. I can use them with my iPod but not my laptop.

    Rating: 4

    2012-06-20: These headphones were probably the most durable corded headphones I have used in a long time. I used these headphones for around 4 hours a day, 5 days a week for 8 months before they finally began to short in one and eventually both ears. However, their longevity was extended by the two part cord, the bottom part of which went after about 3 months. This compares to an average life of about 3 weeks for a pair of skullcandy headphones.And now the pros and consPros:1) Build quality: Top quality flat cord helps prevent tangles and also reduces strain on the headphone ends.2) In line volume, ff/rw and pause play: another feature that increases life as the less often you pull your phone out the less strain you put on the cord.3) decent microphone quality.4) Two stage cord.5) Storage bag: Came with a zippered bag for storing when not in use, which always helps reduce damage to the phones and increase life.Cons:1) Poor audio quality: sound was both tinny and lacked strong bass. I listen to a lot of audiobooks and even in that non-intense media I could detect a marked decrease in sound quality as compared to other headphones I have used.2) Main cord is too short: Another couple of inches and the main cord by itself would have reached comfortably to my pants pocket. I found that once the extension broke, I had to keep the cord in a jacket pocket, which was much less conveinent.3) No offset headphone jack. An offset jack would have reduced strain on the connections further and increased durability further.4) UNBELIEVABLY UNCOMFORTABLE: I used these headphones because I try to only replace headphones when they break. But these were some of the most uncomfortable headphones I have ever used. No matter which attachment I used my ears would start to feel bruised after about 40 minuets, and at times I almost felt like the headphones were cutting into my ears.Conclusion:Although these headphones lasted a long time (relatively) I kinda wished they hadn't. Between poor sound quality and poor comfort these left a lot to be desired. I would recommend finding another pair of headphones that have a flat cord, or even better splurging a little bit for a decent pair of Bluetooth headphones, that way you won't have to worry about damaging the cord. Don't however, buy these headphones.

    Rating: 2

    2013-02-12: Got these and knew who could evaluate them best: my daughter who is a triathlete. She uses these now during her riding and running training phases and reports they haven't failed her yet. Stay in place, provide quality well balanced sound with no movement static or feedback. A keeper, she reports.

    Rating: 4

    2012-06-11: Gave these Jabra SPORT headphones to my 11 year old son in hopes that he could FINALLY find a pair that would fit his ears comfortable... and stay in! These were just what he was looking for and he loves the shape and color. He likes to wear these when he's on a run with me and we were pleasantely surprised when they stayed in entire time. An added bonus was the clip he uses to attach the cord to his shirt - no more floppy cord flying around in his face while running. The sound and durability confirm to me that I won't be in the market for a new pair for a long time... unless he loses them! Ugh!

    Rating: 4

    2011-09-22: The Jabra Sport headset provides a welcome change from earbuds for use when exercising; gone are the days of trying to maintain your stride/focus while re-seating an earbud. By looping comfortably around your ear, these stay firmly in place, without any need for adjustment. The sound quality is more than adequate, although, to be fair, not on the same par as some of the high end earbuds on the market. Moreover, the cord includes an extension, so if you carry your player in a case on your arm, it can be removed to prevent excess cord from flopping around. Moreover, there is a clip on the cord to further prevent movement, as well as a small set of buttons that control volume and skip tracks; it is worth mentioning hear that while these are sold as for Apple devices only, they worked just fine with my Motorola Droid X, with the exception of volume control.On the downside, as other reviewers have mentioned, the earpieces are a little on the large side, which I suppose is necessary to hold them in place, but the result is that over time they can become...uncomfortable may be too strong a word, but certainly annoying. The point is you are aware they are there, rather than other smaller earbuds, which I tend to forget about after a few songs. This is the price you pay for them to stay in place during exercise, but the point is you probably won't want to wear them to listen to music at the grocery store or while lying around the house, it's just not what they are made for.All in and all, I am very pleased with this headset. The design is thoughtful, the sound quality is good, and above all they stay in place.

    Rating: 4

    2011-10-19: I've been looking for a hardy set of earphones to use while running/biking. The last pair I had lasted all of a couple months before they give into the jostling and pressure caused by my intense, lightning speed workouts. The Apple earbuds last a little longer, but they eventually fail as well. I needed something bigger, faster, stronger.Enter Jabra SPORT headset. These puppies are heavy-duty and seem very durable. They're also not terribly heavy, which is nice and they fit nicely around the ear, which gives the cord more support when I'm jumping over small cars or flying up Everest-ish mountains. The sound quality is great too. Good volume and an even EQ balance between bass and treble. There's a handy volume control, a microphone (for those ever-important phone calls while you're tearing up 13.1), and an extension cord that works nicely to adjust the cord from arm-based music player to a hand or pocket-based player.This specific product works with iPod, iPhone, and iPad (not sure what kind of extreme sporting activities you'll be doing with a tablet computer, but these headphones allow that) with in-line volume control and a remote to answer calls. It doesn't guarantee the quality of your phone call while you're trucking down the trails, but it guarantees that you can make them!Overall, this is a great product in its functionality and performance- and it's long-lasting (so far). A great buy!*** As it turns out, Jabra also has excellent customer service. You should feel very confident with your purchase.

    Rating: 5

    2011-09-22: First off, the add on gel ear pieces are a pain to use. They really don't help at all.Unlike the ones by Bose, which are really snug and blocks outside noise just right.These are too big even for the default ones, so after wearing them for 30 min, my ears hurt.It also feels quite heavy and burdensome.The thin cord itself is really nice, bright yellw and very strong.The problem is the basic cord (without the extension) is toooooo short. I know this is meant for a sports, jugging use, but it is still too short. I think 6 more inches would make it perfect.With that said, the extension is a joke. The female plug is way tooo lose. I used it a few times and sometimes just lightly pulling the cord would result the cord coming lose from the extension cord.The included pouch is a great thing and they must include this because of the fact you never know when you might need the extension cable.The sound: quality is mediocre at best.There's no base, the high's not clear or crisp enough. The mid sounds not rich enough.For $70, I would expect the sound quality to be above average, at least not too inferior to senheiser low end or bose mid grade products. But this is by far very low end sound quality, maybe a $15-20 range.I guess Jabra is good at making phone heasets but not stereo headphones. So, you have to use this on a phone to appreciate it since they expect the user to care more about phone call quality than music enjoyment.Also, there's a basic design flaw in this.With the ear overhang design, they intended for you to hang the cord to your back then down to the arm where you have your ipod nano or other tiny MP3 music players. How would that help when you have a phone call? The mic and the buttons on the cord are now on your back, how would you press it?If they designed this and the length of cord, is intended for an arm-placement music player, why would you design it so the buttons are behind your neck? (how can one talk to the mic which is behind the buttons?)Someone please tell me what's the reason behind that?So far, I have not seen anyone wearing an iPhone on their arm while jugging. It is too heavy.If you say this is for putting the iPhone on the rack when you use the running treadmill, then, I ask again, why would you put the cord buttons to the back of your neck? So, there's a basic design flaw in my opinion.Anyhow, to wrap it up, I would not recomend this product unless they improve upon the tonal quality first and then at least improve the extension cord attachment plug and the minimum length of the main cord.Then, lower the price to about $59 retail. It should sell well.3 stars.

    Rating: 3

    2011-10-03: I have never been a big fan of over-the-ear headphones, finding them difficult to position and with subpar audio quality, and these headphones did not change my opinion. If you want headphones that are easy to use and offer great audio quality - I would move on to buds.However, if you do want over-the-ear for a variety of good reasons, I think the Jabra's are a very good choice. While a bit difficult to mount on your ears, once you do have them in place they hold quite well. They are very well constructed, and I especially like the heavy duty short cord - and the longer extension. It tends not to tangle like standard cords. And they are the best sounding over-the-ear phones I have experienced - so overall a very good choice if this is the style of headphone you are looking for.

    Rating: 4

    2011-09-21: The positives:- can withstand rain- rubberize plastic all over- nice feel- Does not overcompensate the bass (Very common for earphones to do this)- Good natural soundNOTE:If you are thinking this might work with Android - don't waste your time. It does not. While the audio obviously works, neither the volume controls nor the answer call button work at all.I am not marking it down due to this - I just know that sometimes manufacturers says it only works with X product when in reality it works with more. This one does not. Only with Apple devices.Two warnings:A friend with smaller ears tried these on and they were simply too big, she tried to arrange these to see if she could get them to work, but to no avail.So if you have small ears, I suggest you pass on this pair.These fit me just fine, however, the feel quite lose, and they kept moving away from the year (not quite falling out, but to the point where I couldn't hear one side very well), this even with light excercise.     Rating: 4

    2011-09-20: I really wanted to like these because I have been looking for a quality headset to go running for ages. However, it really wasn't to be. On first glance, the quality of the headset and the cord are very good. The rubber seems strong and resistant to tearing while each ear-piece looks very water resistant. However, from that point on, I had some difficulties with the headset. First, I couldn't really get the ear loops to hold the headset snugly in place. Jabra notes that they can be bent to a more comfortable position but they never seemed to stay in place. Second, the eargels didn't really secure the earphone into my ear canal. Candidly, they fit no better than your standard iPhone headsets. As a result, the sound quality of the speakers is pretty lackluster: blaring midrange, shattering treble and bass that wasn't tight and responsive. Now, maybe I am not giving enough credit to the fact that these are sports earphones but I do like nice audio when I'm working out and alas, these just couldn't do the job well for me. Perhaps if you can make a better fit the sound would be better, but I wasn't able to do so.So, 2 stars: quality construction appears quite good but fit and audio quality were big detractors.

    Rating: 2

    2011-09-22: These Jabra Sport headphones did not offer any redeeming quality to me. First, the rubber eargels were extremely difficult to get on the headset. They didn't just pop right on, you had to really work them on. Second, the headphones don't stay attached to your ears. Unless your ear is perfectly shape to conform to the headsets, it is a bad fit. I bended them and they stayed in place for a few seconds and then popped of my ear. Maybe I'm just not used to this style of headset as this is my first pair of the style, but you shouldn't have to work this hard to get earphones to stay in your ear. When I did actually get to listen to my iPod, the sound quality was fine, but certainly nothing to write home about. As for the cord, it is a nice feature with the clip and extension, but certainly not enough to save this headset from being substandard.

    Rating: 1

    2011-09-20: Pros:1. These headphone deliver above average sound quality. I'm comparing them to the white earbud headphones that come with an iPhone or iPod. There is a little more bass and treble sounds good. They are able to be played quite loud without distortion2. The headphones stay in my ears while working out. Just tested them out on a 30 minute jog and had no issues with them coming off (or even moving out of position) while using them. Definitely a plus compared to standard earbud headphones3. There is a handy clip that can be used to secure the cord to your shirt. Keeps the cord from flopping around during a run. Nice touch.4. The headphones are connected to a 2 foot cord and come with a 2 foot cord extension. I love this feature. I have a jogging pullover coat that has a zipper pocket in the sleeve. When I put my iPod in it, I only need about 1 foot of cord to get the headphones to my ears. Using the headphones without the extension cord for this gets rid of a lot of unnecessary cord that I would have to tuck into my coat. But then if I want a longer cord I have the option. I think all headphones should do this.5. There is a nice +/- volume control about 8" down the right earphone cord. It also has the ability to pause and start music playback. Hand especially if you're using your iPod in a zipped pocket and you would like to control the volume without having to access the device.Cons:1. The earbuds start to become uncomfortable after a while. The part that fits in my ear seems a bit large, and after about 45 minutes of use I'm ready to take them out. This is using the smallest of 3 rubber eargels. Using the earbuds without an eargel causes them to become less stable in the ear and they tend to get dislodged from the ear when running. Someone with larger ears may not have this issue. Although they do become a bit uncomfortable after a period of use, I still plan on using them to workout because of all the other benefits they provide.2. The headphones come with a compact case, which is nice for travel, but getting them, along with 4 feet of cord can be a bit tricky. I would have preferred a slightly larger case that would be easier to get the headphones in.Overall I like these headphones, they are great for working out and provide reasonable sound quality.

    2011-09-28: I have been a fan of Jabra devices ever since I bought my Jabra Bluetooth that allowed me to listen to music via my phone.     2011-09-20: If you were to judge this product by what you see on the outside packaging, you would never know about the extra features that make these headphones stand apart from the others.For example:* Paired with Endomondo's app, you can get your updated workout stats READ ALOUD TO YOU through the headset!* Military rated for rain, dust, and shock protection!* With the "control box" (or what looks like a buil-in microphone) you canTake phone calls (and end them)Adjust volumePlay or Pause musicSkip to the next trackControl the Voice-Over feature of your Apple device.     2011-09-21: These earphones come with a couple of cool touches -- they have an extension so you can wear it clipped to your shoulder (without extra cord getting in the way) or in your pocket if you need the full length. They also have a volume button in easy reach that works with the phone. I used these on a recent jog, and I found these functions quite useful.But on the minus side, the sound isn't that great. It's okay for spoken word, but sucky for music. Also, I'm used to noise-canceling phones, and like those much better. With these, I can hear everything, which is okay for running outside, but would be horrible in a gym, where they'd be competing with the music over the speakers. So these will only be for back-up; I'm sticking to my regular pair.
